description: The Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray (Mobula munkiana) is a medium-sized (to 110 cm disc width) ray that is limited to shallow, tropical Eastern Pacific waters from the Gulf of California to Peru down to depths of 30 m. The Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray has an extremely low reproductive output with only one pup born per litter, and is therefore likely to have very low productivity incapable of withstanding and recovering from even very low levels of fishing mortality. Increasing international trade in gill plates has led to the expansion of largely unregulated and unmonitored devil ray (Mobula spp.) fisheries. The species is a target of large artisanal fisheries in MÃ©xico and Peru, and is taken as bycatch of small- and large-scale fisheries, with much of this catch likely unreported or aggregated and reported as Mobula spp. There are no current or historical estimates of the population size and trend of the Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray, and further information is required from throughout its range. Based on distribution data, high catchability due to its schooling behaviour, limited productivity, directed and targeted fisheries, ongoing demand in trade, and a dataset showing declines in devil ray sighting records around Cocos Island, it is suspected that the Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray may have been depleted in areas where significant fisheries or threats for mobulids exist. There are likely some refuges from fishing, for example in Ecuador's GalÃ¡pagos Marine Resources Reserve and while it should be noted that illegal fishing is an ongoing issue in the reserve, this refuge suggests that this species may not be at a level of extinction risk characteristic of some other mobuild rays. Overall, it is suspected that this species has undergone a reduction of ~30â€“49% over the last three generations (38 years), with a further population reduction suspected over the next three generation lengths (2018â€“2056). Therefore, the Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray is assessed as Vulnerable (VU A2d+3d).
trade: The Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray is used for its meat, skin, cartilage, liver oil, and gill plates. The meat from mobulid rays, including the Munk's Pygmy Devil Ray, is often used locally or traded regionally for human consumption, animal feed, and shark bait (Fernando and Stevens 2011, Heinrichs et al. 2011, Couturier et al. 2012, Croll et al. 2016). The cartilage, the skin, which is commonly used for leather products (shoes, wallets, and knife handles), and the gill plates are exported to Asia (Heinrichs et al. 2011, Couturier et al. 2012, Croll et al. 2016, Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. 2017). The gill plates in particular fetch high prices in Asia and are used for Chinese health tonics (Oâ€™Malley et al. 2017).

description: The Sicklefin Devil Ray (Mobula tarapacana) is a large (at least 370 cm disc width) ray that has a circumglobal but patchy distribution in temperate, subtropical, and tropical waters of the Indian, Pacific, and Atlantic oceans. The species is primarily oceanic, with populations mostly occurring in areas of high upwelling-related productivity, but can also be found in coastal waters and to depths of 1,896 m. Little is known about its biology and ecology, although it is inferred from other Mobula species to produce a single pup every one to three years, and therefore, it is slow to recover from overfishing.Increasing trade in gill plates and meat has led to the expansion of largely unregulated and unmonitored mobulid ray (Mobula spp.) fisheries worldwide. The Sicklefin Devil Ray is captured as target and incidental catch in industrial and small-scale purse seine and gillnet fisheries, and is retained for its meat and gill plates. It is a large component of these fisheries in Sri Lanka, Indonesia, and India, but across its global range, much of this catch remains unreported. The limited species-specific catch, fishing effort, and population data necessitates the use of genus-wide inferences to assess population reductions. Where documented, Mobula catches and landings have steadily decreased despite stable or increasing fishing effort, indicating global populations have also declined. Since the 2000s, significant population reductions have been estimated, suspected, or inferred in many regions, including Southeast Asia, the Eastern Pacific, and the Indian Ocean, where mobulid rays are heavily exploited.Overall, the available data show severe population reductions of mobulid rays in several regions, with suspected local and regional reductions of 50â€“99% over the last three generation lengths (48 years). Less information is available in other regions (e.g., Atlantic Ocean), but it is suspected, based on known threats and general declines reported for mobulid rays, that those populations are in decline as well. While wide-ranging movements and migration possibly connect regions, and steep local declines may reflect a global population reduction, caution is needed when extrapolating regional declines to a global population reduction, especially as the Sicklefin Devil Ray has a widespread global distribution which likely includes some areas of lower fishing pressure (e.g., Australia). Nonetheless, based on current and future potential levels of exploitation, steep declining trends in monitored populations, and the uncertainty of data in some regions, it is suspected and inferred that the Sicklefin Devil Ray global population has undergone a reduction >80% over the past three generation lengths (48 years), with a further population reduction suspected over the next three generation lengths (2025â€“2073) due to ongoing demand for high-value products. The Sicklefin Devil Ray is therefore assessed as Critically Endangered (CR A2bd+3d).This species was assessed as Endangered (EN) in 2018. However, improved data on population trends across regions has confirmed that the species warrants a CR status (i.e., had this information been available in 2018, the species would have been assessed as CR). However, the threats to this species have also been increasing in recent years, particularly through increased pressure from international trade in gill plates.
trade: The Sicklefin Devil Ray is primarily used for its dried prebranchial appendages (commonly called gill plates) and meat (Palacios et al. 2025). However, in some regions, mobulid liver, cartilage, intestines, and fin tips may also be utilised for human consumption (White et al. 2006a, Acebes and Tull 2016, Piovano and Gilman 2017, Steinke et al. 2017, Palacios et al. 2025), likely as a byproduct of the gill plate and meat trade. In some countries, Sicklefin Devil Ray meat is also used for animal feed and shark bait (Fernando and Stevens 2011, Heinrichs et al. 2011, Couturier et al. 2012, Ender and Fernando 2014, Lewis et al. 2015, Croll et al. 2016, Palacios et al. 2025, F. Doumbouya, pers. comm. 11/10/2015). In Peru, the skin is sometimes removed and dried with other fish products to make fertilizers for plants (Rojas-Perea et al. 2025).Mobulid gill plates are extracted in at least 14 countries and exported across Asia and Africa by land, air, or sea (Palacios et al. 2025). South Korea, mainland China, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR), Singapore and Thailand are the major destinations for gill plates (Heinrichs et al. 2011, Couturier et al. 2012, Croll et al. 2016, Notarbartolo-di-Sciara et al. 2017, Palacios et al. 2025). Gill plates are used for Chinese health tonics and fetch prices of 4.8 to 1,260 USD/kg with an average price of 511.81 USD/kg (Oâ€™Malley et al. 2017, Palacios et al. 2025). Since 2013, Hong Kong SAR and mainland Chinaâ€™s gill plate markets have shifted from physical storefronts to mostly online platforms, making tracking more challenging (Palacios et al. 2025). The large size (average 25â€“30 cm total length), smooth lobe edging, and black and white (thick white centre) bicolouration of Sicklefin Devil Ray gill plates make this species easily identifiable in the gill plate trade (Stevens et al. 2025). These â€˜flower gillsâ€™ fetch the second highest price after manta ray (Oceanic Manta Ray (M. birostris) and Reef Manta Ray (M. alfredi)) gill plates and are one of the three most traded mobulid species; along with the Oceanic Manta Ray and Spinetail Devil Ray (M. mobular) (Zeng et al. 2016, Oâ€™Malley et al. 2017, Palacios et al. 2025).Sicklefin Devil Ray meat is considered low quality in most regions and is not believed to drive target fisheries (Palacios et al. 2025). Mobulid meat is traded predominantly for human consumption and may be eaten fresh, but is usually frozen, salted, or sun-dried (Palacios et al. 2025). It is consumed in at least 35 countries and traded mostly at a domestic level in South America, Africa, and Asia (Palacios et al. 2025). In Sri Lanka, whilst considered low quality meat, Sicklefin Devil Ray meat is the most valuable amongst mobulid rays (Blue Resources Trust pers. comm. 25/03/2025). Mobulid meat consumption in Peru, Guatemala, Mexico, Bangladesh, and the Philippines is connected to cultural traditions, and this local consumption is often the main driver of utilization (Palacios et al. 2025). For example, in Peru, mobulid meat is consumed both dried and fresh, but there is no apparent marketing or sale of gill plates (Ayala and Romero 2016, Alfaro-Cordova et al. 2017, Rojas-Perea et al. 2025). However, in the Republic of the Congo, where mobulid meat is also consumed locally in the vicinity of the landing sites, there are also â€œluxury goodsâ€ traders at the landing sites, with gill plates comprising part of their business (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2025). Globally, there are at least ten countries exporting mobulid meat, trading across land and sea to five major destination countries (Myanmar, mainland China, Thailand, Peru, and United Arab Emirates) (Palacios et al. 2025).There are isolated reports of Sicklefin Devil Rays being winged (pectoral fins removed), but in most instances it is unclear how these are utilised (Acebes and Tull 2016, Piovano and Gilman 2017). Surveys with fishers in Margarita Island, Venezuela, indicate that they sometimes cut wing tips off mobulids and sell them as shark fins (L. Zambrano pers. comm. 22/03/2025), or that they are used as filler for shark fin soup (White et al. 2006a). Indeed, an analysis of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Flora (CITES) Trade Database (2017â€“2023), highlighted examples of mobulid fin trade reported by Sri Lanka (1,030 kg), Yemen (2,222 kg) and Oman (88 kg) (CITES Secretariat and UNEP-WCMC 2023). However, given the small number of reports, and lack of evidence of mobulid fins in the Hong Kong SAR markets, it seems more likely these shipments were a coding error in the CITES Trade Database (Palacios et al. 2025). Similarly, the CITES Trade Database documents several exports of mobulid skin from Sri Lanka to Hong Kong SAR (including Sicklefin Devil Ray). However, there is no evidence from researchers on the ground that these animals are being processed for this use in these countries (D. Fernando unpubl. data 2025), and, as with the fin trade records, it is suspected these records are a result of a coding error.

description: The Bentfin Devil Ray (Mobula thurstoni) is a large (to 197 cm disc width) ray that has a circumglobal but patchy distribution in temperate, subtropical, and tropical waters worldwide. It occurs in both shallow, neritic waters and in pelagic waters from the surface to depths of 440 m. The species has one of the largest distributions of all the mobulids, but populations occur most often in highly productive upwelling areas. The Bentfin Devil Ray has an extremely low reproductive output with a single pup born every one to three years, and is therefore likely to have very low productivity, and therefore, it is slow to recover from overfishing.Increasing trade in gill plates and meat has led to the expansion of largely unregulated and unmonitored mobulid ray (Mobula spp.) fisheries worldwide. The Bentfin Devil Ray is captured as target and incidental catch in industrial and small-scale purse seine and gillnet fisheries and is retained for its meat and gill plates. It is a large component of these fisheries in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Peru, and the Philippines but across much of its global range, much of this catch remains unreported. The limited species-specific catch, fishing effort, and population data necessitates the use of genus-wide inferences to assess population reductions. Where documented, Mobula catches and landings have steadily decreased despite stable or increasing fishing effort, indicating globally populations have also declined. Since the 2000s, significant population reductions have been estimated, suspected, or inferred in many regions including Southeast Asia, the Eastern Pacific, and the Indian Ocean where mobulid rays are heavily exploited. Overall, the available data show severe population reductions of mobulid rays in several regions (e.g., Western Indian Ocean), with suspected local and regional declines of 50â€“99% over the last three generation lengths (36 years). Less information is available in other regions (e.g., Atlantic Ocean), but it is suspected, based on known threats and general declines reported for mobulid rays, that those populations are in decline as well. While wide-ranging movements and migration possibly connect regions and steep local declines may reflect a global population reduction, caution is needed extrapolating regional declines to a global population reduction, especially as the Bentfin Devil Ray has a widespread global distribution which includes some areas of lower fishing pressure (e.g., Australia). Nonetheless, based on current and future potential levels of exploitation, steep declining trends in monitored populations, and the uncertainty of data in some regions, it is suspected that the Bentfin Devil Ray global population has undergone a reduction >80% over the past three generation lengths (36 years), with a further population reduction suspected over the next three generation lengths (2025â€“2061) due to ongoing demand for high-value products. The Bentfin Devil Ray is therefore assessed as Critically Endangered (CR A2bd+3d).This species was assessed as Endangered (EN) in 2018. However, improved data on population trends across regions has confirmed that the species warrants a CR status (i.e., had this information been available in 2018, the species would have been assessed as CR). However, the threats to this species have also been increasing in recent years, particularly through increased pressure from international trade in gill plates.

description: The Whitenose Shark (Nasolamia velox) is a small (to 150 cm total length) requiem shark that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from Baja California, Mexico, to Peru over the continental shelf to a depth of 192 m. It is captured in artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries and in industrial shrimp trawls throughout its range. Landings records of sharks from the Gulf of California artisanal fisheries, where gillnet fishing pressure is intense, indicate a decline in Whitenose Shark landings from 600 t in 1969 to 200 t in 2014 (with fishing ongoing). Targeted fisheries for sharks including the Whitenose Shark off Mazatlan were in operation by the early 1960s. In Guatemala in the 1990s, this was the second-most abundant shark in artisanal fisheries, but in 2006â€“2007 landings surveys, this species was encountered at lower levels, and two years of surveys from 2017â€“2018 only recorded two individuals. In Costa Rica, trawl surveys conducted between 2008 and 2012 failed to record the species even though it was present there in the 1980s. Catches in Colombia were relatively common in the 1990s, but it has rarely been recorded since. A few individuals were recorded in Peruvian landings in the late 1990s, but it has not been recorded since.Â Â Mangrove habitats, which often serve as nursery areas for coastal sharks such as this, have been degraded with the development of shrimp aquaculture in many areas of the Eastern Central Pacific.Â Overall, due to the level of intense and unmanaged fisheries across its range, combined with an increasing rarity of records, limited biological productivity, and habitat degradation, the Whitenose Shark is suspected to have undergoneÂ a population reduction of 50â€“79% over the past three generations (27 years), and it is assessed as Endangered A2cd.
trade: This shark is retained and the meat is consumed locally. Fins may be exported internationally.
cites: Appendix II:Listing adopted at CoP19 in November 2022 with entry into effect delayed by 12 months.

description: The Sharptooth Lemon SharkÂ (Negaprion acutidens) is a large (to 340 cm total length) coastal shark that is widespread throughout the Indo-West and Central Pacific.Â It is demersal in shallow inshore and offshore waters to at least 90 m depth and is often found on and around coral reefs and on sandy plateaus near coral. It is also known to occur around and within mangrove forests, which may be used as nursery grounds. It is caught as target and bycatch through much of its range in industrial and small-scale fisheries using longline, gillnet, handline, and demersal trawl. This species is also threatened by declines in habitat quality of coral reefs due to climate change, destructive fishing practices, and poor water quality; and mangroves from deforestation and coastal development. While there is limited species-specific data available, it is likely to have undergone declines based on its large size and presumably low productivity, and intensive coastal fisheries through much of its range. Landings surveys, dive surveys, diver interviews, and anecdotal evidence indicate substantial declines over the past three generations lengths (50 years). Results from baited remote underwater video system surveys of coral reefs across its range (242 reefs in 36 nations) indicate that the species has declined to very low levels through much of its range in Asia and Africa, but remains common in Australia, and in some island nations of the Pacific and Indian Oceans. It is estimated that the Sharptooth Lemon Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50â€“79% over the last three generation lengths (50 years) due to levels of exploitation and declines in habitat quality, and it is assessed as Endangered A2bcd.
trade: The meat of the Sharptooth Lemon Shark is used fresh, dried, salted, frozen, or smoked. Fields et al. (2018) reported that Sharptooth Lemon Shark made up 0.6% of fin trimmings sold in Hong Kong. The species is occasionally displayed in aquaria. In the Western and Central Pacific, the species is a key component of the tourism industry where diving and interactions with this shark regularly occur. It is estimated that the species generates around $5.4 million USD per year within a shark feeding ecotourism operation in French Polynesia (Clua et al.2011).
cites: Appendix II:Listing adopted at CoP19 in November 2022 with entry into effect delayed by 12 months.

description: The Lemon Shark (Negaprion brevirostris) is a large (to 340 cm total length) shark found in the Atlantic and Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific, ranging from Virginia, United States of America, to southern Brazil including the Caribbean Sea in the western Atlantic and from Mauritania to Angola, including Cape Verde and SÃ£o TomÃ© and PrÃ­ncipe, in the eastern Atlantic. It ranges from northern Mexico to Ecuador in the eastern Pacific. The species inhabits shallow inshore tropical and subtropical waters around coral reefs and mangrove fringes on continental and insular shelves from the surface to a depth of 92 m. It is taken mainly in artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries, which are intense and largely unmanaged throughout its range.This species was formerly common in the Gulf of California in the 1960s but has since become rare there and extensive surveys of multiple landings sites in 1998â€“1999 did not encounter this species. Similar patterns of decline occurred in Brazil where it is considered extinct in the state of SÃ£o Paulo and there have been no recent records in Rio de Janeiro, SÃ£o Paulo, and EspÃ­rito Santo. In the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, this species now appears to be rare, yet it was formerly abundant in Banc Dâ€™Arguin, Mauritania, and it has been depleted by the 1990s and not seen there since 2009. This species now only seems common in the Cape Verde and is rare elsewhere in West Africa. Artisanal and commercial target and bycatch fishing pressure is intense and management is lacking throughout much of its range. It is suspected that the Lemon Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50â€“79% over the past three generation lengths (50 years) in approximately three-quarters of its range in the Southwest and Eastern Central Atlantic and the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific, however, this species is likely to be stable in the Western Central and Northwest Atlantic part of its range which likely has significant fraction of suitable habitat and lower fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Lemon Shark has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the past three generation lengths (50 years)Â based on abundance indices, regional decline in area of occupancy, and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bcd.
trade: Lemon shark are utilized primarily for meat and fins and comprise 0.46% of the fin trade, based on trimming of shark fins from Hong Kong in 2014â€“2015 (CardeÃ±osaÂ et al.Â 2020). The rough and heavy skin has made the lemon shark one of the preferred species among tanneries for the production of leather. In parts of its range it is also valued for its liver oil. The Lemon Shark is routinely viewed by recreational snorkellers and SCUBA divers, and is a popular aquarium species.
cites: Appendix II:Listing adopted at CoP19 in November 2022 with entry into effect delayed by 12 months.
