description: The Discus Stingray (Paratrygon aiereba) is a large (to 160 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater ray known from the Amazon and Essequibo basins across Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia. Despite its wide distribution range, populations are concentrated in some main river channels, and there is evidence of the existence of a species complex in some river basins. It has a very low fecundity (average 2 pups per litter per year) with a generation length estimated as 10 years. The species is heavily targeted for consumption by unregulated fishing activities, it is also illegally captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade, and subject to environmental impacts (mining, agricultural development) in the Amazon Region. The main threat is fishing pressure, with unsustainable targeting of the Discus Stingray having increased dramatically in the past 25 years along with an expansion of its fishing grounds along the Amazon River. In Brazil, a population reduction of at least 80% was estimated for the past three generation lengths (30 years). In the neighbouring countries, a very similar scenario probably is taking place since there is an increasing demand of the species for food consumption. This species has been indicated as one the potamotrygonins with the highest intrinsic susceptibility to extinction. Considering that the Discus Stingray is a fisheries targeted species and subject to habitat quality declines, and increasing environmental impacts including pollutants, it is inferred to have undergone a population reduction of at least 80% over the past three generation lengths (30 years). Thus, the Discus Stingray is assessed as Critically Endangered A2bcde.
trade: Since the Discus Stingray grows to considerable size, captures for ornamental purposes target neonates and juvenile specimens. The international ornamental aquarium trade of the Discus Stingray is considered very low when compared to other Potamotrygon species. The species is occasionally illegally exported to the ornamental aquarium trade from Brazil (AraÃºjo et al. 2004). It is also exported from Colombia and the main exporter is Peru (Prang 2020a). In the ornamental trade the species is known as Ceja and Manzana Ray and its trade codes are: P56, P57, R113, R114, R115, R116, R118, R119 (Ross and Schaffer 2000, Prang 2020a). The Discus Stingray is considered to have the highest meat-carcass ration of all potamotrygonins. It is captured and traded for consumption in local, national (Brazil), and international markets (Charvet-Almeida and Almeida 2008, AraÃºjo 2011, Camacho-Oliveira et al. 2020, Charvet et al 2022, Gama person. comm. 2021).
cm_name: Ceja ray, Discus ray, Manzana ray
country: Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of)

description: The TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon albimaculata) is a small (up to 55 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the TapajÃ³s River basin in Brazil, primarily occurring in the main channel of the upper to middle TapajÃ³s River. The species' dorsal colour pattern makes it highly valued in the international ornamental aquarium trade. Mainly adults are targeted and have been illegally captured and traded from Brazil since the 1980s at levels of up to at least 15,000 individuals per year from 2000â€“2006, with ongoing high levels of capture and trade. The TapajÃ³s River basin region has been severely impacted by habitat degradation, including pollutants, in the past decades due to legal and illegal mining and agricultural activities which have occurred in almost 60% of this speciesâ€™ range. Thus, it is suspected that the TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population reduction of at least 30% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to significant habitat degradation, levels of exploitation, and pollutants, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cde.
trade: The TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray has been captured for the international ornamental market for at least the past three decades and captures target mainly adult specimens. The species is considered of high commercial value in the international ornamental aquarium trade due to its dorsal color pattern (AraÃºjo 2004). The trade code for this species is P-14 and the trade common name is Itaituba Ray (Ross and Schaeffer 2000).Between 2000â€“2006, about 15,000 individuals of this species were illegally exported from Brazil, the species has been exported under incorrect names, such as Xingu Freshwater Stingray (P. leopoldi) or Henle's Freshwater Stingray (P. henlei) (M.L.G. AraÃºjo unpubl. data 2022). Currently, most individuals on the market come from Asian captivity breeding facilities (Prang 2020). Prior to this, broodstock were traded from Brazil, for example, in 2015â€“2017 many females were exported illegally from Brazil to Asian countries to be used as breeding stock in captive breeding facilities. Since 2017, illegal exports from Brazil have decreased since the ornamental market seemed to have shifted interest to hybrid morphs of Xingu Freshwater Stingray (P. leopoldi) and Pearl Freshwater Stingray (P. jabuti).
country: Brazil

description: The Amandaâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon amandae) is medium-sized species (to 65 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray with a relatively wide geographic distribution in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, and Paraguay, and mainly in the ParanÃ¡-Paraguay River basin. The species is expanding its distribution area, occupying new areas in the Upper ParanÃ¡ Region, southeastern Brazil, after natural barriers were removed. It is a low fecundity species (1â€“3 pups) that is targeted for the international ornamental aquarium trade and has been subject to negative fishery (tail mutilation and killing), mainly out of its native range of occurrence. It is also occasionally taken for consumption by local communities. Since this species has been expanding its native range of occurrence and seems to adapt well to new habitats, it has been considered an invasive species in some regions adjacent to its original distribution area, leading to a suspected population increase. Therefore, the Amandaâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Least Concern.
trade: The species is targeted for the international ornamental aquarium trade. The skin of this species has also been tested by the shoe industry, but there is no updated data on this topic (D. Garrone-Neto pers. comm. 2022). Artisanal fishers, indigenous, and riparian people consume the species when it is accidentally caught.
country: Argentina, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Paraguay

description: The Giant Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon brachyura) is the largest Neotropical potamotrygonin freshwater stingray (up to 176 cm disc width and over 200 kg), endemic to the ParanÃ¡-La Plata River basin and found mainly in large floodplain rivers of northeastern Argentina, south central-west and south Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Its fecundity is relatively high compared with other potamotrygonins (average 8â€“10 pups per litter) but a low estimated maximum population increase rate of 0.15â€“0.19 per year. The Giant Freshwater Stingray is targeted in subsistence and commercial fisheries for its meat for human consumption. It is also targeted as a trophy fish in recreational fisheries and captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade. Environmental impacts and habitat degradation caused by damming, agriculture, livestock farming, pollution, urban and industrial development and droughts linked to climate change are also threats for the Giant Freshwater Stingray. In approximately one fifth of its distribution range, a steep population decline (90%), mainly due to fishing pressure, has been estimated over the past three generation lengths (59 years). In the remaining distribution range of this species, fishing pressure is lower yet ongoing. Considering this and combined with life history traits that make it susceptible to overexploitation, an overall population reduction of at least 30% is inferred over the past three generation lengths (59 years), leading the Giant Freshwater Stingray to be assessed as Vulnerable (VU A2bcde). Nevertheless, additional, more specific data on population trends, or the increase, or development of some of the currently potential habitat modification threats (e.g., dam construction, waterway development) will require the Giant Freshwater Stingray to be reassessed in the near future.
trade: The Giant Freshwater Stingray is targeted in subsistence and commercial fisheries for its meat, which is used for human consumption. It is also targeted as a trophy fish in recreational fisheries, and captured for the international aquarium trade. The Giant Freshwater Stingray is caught mainly for human consumption throughout almost all of its range, with the highest levels of commercial fishing pressure in the Middle and Lower ParanÃ¡ River. In that region, the species is targeted during spring and summer (November to March) by commercial fishers, using specially-designed longlines (Castello and Jones 2016). The stingrays caught are all dressed in the field, conserved on ice, and sold to fish mongers in the domestic market.Â Giant Freshwater Stingray meat is routinely offered to the public in fish markets, bars and restaurants in the main riverine cities (e.g., Santa Fe, Rosario, ParanÃ¡), during summer (L.O. Lucifora, pers. obs. 2024). Juveniles are normally released alive by fishers, but subadults are retained, as they are perceived as â€œlarge enoughâ€. In general, this fishery catches almost exclusively the Giant Freshwater Stingray. However, occasionally, large individuals (>60 cm disc width) of the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro) are also taken, retained, and sold. In other areas of its geographic range, the Giant Freshwater Stingray is caught in subsistence and commercial fisheries (Castello and Jones 2016, Torres and Charvet 2024). These areas include parts of Argentina (other than the Middle and Lower ParanÃ¡), as well as areas in all other countries where the species occurs. Fishing pressure in these areas is presumably lower than in the Middle and Lower ParanÃ¡ (Scarabotti et al. 2021); nevertheless, its effects on the Giant Freshwater Stingray is ongoing and needs to be further evaluated.The Giant Freshwater Stingray is also caught for recreational fishing throughout its range using rod and reel (Castello and Jones 2016). It is sought after by recreational fishers as a trophy fish, because of its large size, which makes it the biggest fish in the ParanÃ¡-La Plata River basin and one of the largest freshwater fishes of South America, and because of the challenge it represents when caught by rod and reel. Some of the Giant Freshwater Stingrays caught by recreational fishers are released alive; however, many are killed and retained for consumption. There are no studies on the survival rates of Giant Freshwater Stingray after capture and release. Juvenile Giant Freshwater Stingrays and all life stages of other freshwater stingrays are also caught by recreational fishers targeting smaller bony fishes. In Argentina, there are two companies specialized in the recreational fishing of the Giant Freshwater Stingray (Castello and Jones 2016). The Giant Freshwater Stingray is occasionally captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade. There are no reliable or official numbers on quantities exported but captures target mainly neonates and juveniles probably in small quantities due to the large size this species attains. The trade codes for Giant Freshwater Stingray in the aquarium trade are R097 and S65976-3 (Ross and Schaffer 2000). Giant Freshwater Stingray specimens have also been traded under the name Maracaibo River Stingray (Potamotrygon yepezi) applying the trade codes R058 and S66103-2 (Prang 2020).
country: Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay

description: The Rough Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon constellata) is a medium-sized (to at least 55 cm disc width) and poorly-known Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to South America where it occurs in the Amazon River and its affluents through Ecuador, Colombia, and Brazil. There is uncertainty about its taxonomic validity due to morphological similarities with other species. Consequently, the speciesâ€™ potential full range and threats are poorly-known. It is suspected it may be taken as bycatch and used for human consumption, and subject to habitat degradation based on its known range. There is no information on its presence in the international ornamental aquarium trade. Since it is unknown if the fishing pressure or threats to habitat quality are causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information to assess the Rough Freshwater Stingray beyond Data Deficient.
trade: The species is suspected to be used for human consumption, while there is no information on the use of this species for international ornamental aquarium trade. In Ecuador it is likely that, like other Potamotrygonidae rays, their stings are used as spurs for fighting cocks by native peoples of the Kichwa ethnic group (Guarderas and JÃ¡come-Negrete 2013).
country: Brazil, Colombia

description: ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon falkneri) is a medium to large-sized (up to 68 cm in disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray widely distributed in the ParanÃ¡ Basin and Upper Amazon Basin in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay, and Peru. This species has shown the ability to invade and proliferate in areas in the Upper ParanÃ¡ River which are heavily impacted by dams when natural barriers were removed. The species has an average fecundity of two pups per litter with a five-month gestation period observed in captivity. The main use of ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is for the international ornamental aquarium trade but it is also occasionally taken as a food source and exploited only in parts of its rather large geographic range. ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is threatened mainly by habitat degradation and loss but has shown its ability to occupy new areas with a range extension in the upper ParanÃ¡ River after dam constructions. Unregulated and illegal fishing for the ornamental aquarium trade, negative fishery, infrastructure development in part of its range, and climate change effects could also be considered threats for this species. However, the only area where the species is common and population trends have been estimated for freshwater stingrays as a group, the population trend for ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is stable. Therefore, given its large geographic distribution range, its apparent ability to withstand river damming, evidence of a range expansion, and apparently stable population trend where it has been studied, ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Least Concern.
trade: The main use of ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is for the international ornamental aquarium trade but it is also occasionally taken for consumption. It enters the international ornamental aquarium trade mostly from Peru, although small numbers have been exported from Argentina, and the species has also been observed in domestic pet shops in Paraguay (Kyne and Lucifora 2022). This species is also captured and exported from Brazil and Uruguay (Ross and Schaffer 2000). In Brazil, this species was never included in the export quota system for freshwater stingrays.In the ornamental trade, ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray is exported under the names Potamotrygon castexi (junior synonym of P. falkneri, under trade codes P25, P31, P32, P34, P54, R056, R057, R110, R143, R154, S65969, S65972, S65973, S65994, S65997), Potamotrygon cf. garrapaÂ  (a synonym of Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (P. motoro), trade codes R035, S66096-4) and as P. falkneri (trade codes P53, R142, S65996) (Prang 2020a). ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray has been exported mainly to Europe but also to the United States of America market, with prices in Europe (United Kingdom, Germany and Czechia) ranging from USD 120â€“2,737 (Prang 2020b). The species is also occasionally captured for subsistence and local consumption; usually only large individuals (over 10 kg).
cm_name: Largespot river stingray, Reticulated freshwater stingray
country: Argentina, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Paraguay, Peru

description: Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon henlei) is a medium to large (up to 71 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the Tocantins-Araguaia River basin in Brazil. This species has an average fecundity of four pups per litter. It is one of the species captured for the international ornamental trade and may be considered as belonging to the valued â€˜black raysâ€™ group. The range of this species overlaps one of the most anthropogenically impacted regions in the Brazilian Amazon basin, and comprises a great portion of the Cerrado savanna biome, which is also strongly subject to agriculture and livestock farming. Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is subject to various threats, mainly comprising fisheries (bycatch, ornamental, recreational, and negative), habitat loss and degradation, intense damming, mining, agricultural and urban expansion, and climate change. Considering this scenario, a population reduction of at least 30% is suspected over the past three generation lengths (33 years), due to a decline in habitat quality and fishing pressure. Thus, the species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU A2cde).
trade: Similarly to some areas in the Amazon Basin, freshwater stingrays are not traditionally taken for food purposes and therefore, Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is not a target species in the Tocantins River region. Nevertheless, this species is frequently captured as bycatch in other fisheries and subject to tail mutilation (negative fishery sensu Compagno and Cook 1995) before being released back to the water.Â This species has been historically present in the international ornamental aquarium trade since the late 1980â€™s and 1990â€™s with varying demand from the market. Wild caught individuals of this species have been exported under a species-specific and maximum disc width size limit quota system established by the Brazilian government in 2003. The main market is North America and Europe, with especially the albino and hybrids varieties being most valued (reaching up to USD 4,500 per individual) (Prang 2020a,b). Despite not being commonly present in the Asian markets, between 2014â€“2016, Thailand became the main importer while England was the main importer in Europe (Prang 2020a,c). The trade codes for this species are P12 (this specific one also known as â€˜King Henleiâ€™ and the most valued dorsal color patterns), R037, R038, R040, and R041 (Ross and Schaeffer 2000). There is one specific hybrid obtained from the breeding of Xingu Freshwater Stingray (Potmatotrygon leopoldi) with a predominantly black dorsal color (very few whitish spots) and Henle's Freshwater Stingray that is referred to as the â€œBlack Rayâ€ morph in the ornamental trade. Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray belongs to the â€˜black rays' color group, along with the Xingu Freshwater Stingray and TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray (P. albimaculata). Henle's Freshwater Stingray has also been indicated as belonging to the â€˜black raysâ€™ color group along with the Great Freshwater Stingray (P. rex) (Carvalho 2016), however, this is not a consensus among ornamental fish traders. Since 2018, the market interest for Henle's Freshwater Stingray and TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray appears to have declined, particularly after the introduction of the Suriname Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon boesemani) and Marques' Freshwater Stingray (P. marquesi) to the market (Prang 2020c). Between 2005 and 2010, the highest interest was in larger individuals (parental stock), although market demand was lower than for Xingu Freshwater Stingray. The number ofÂ Henle's Freshwater Stingray individuals seized (between 2002â€“2018) accounted for less than 2% of the total quantities seized (Prang 2020b). Hybrids of Henle's Freshwater Stingray are predominantly sold in North America, with prices ranging from USD 700 to USD 900 each, while some of the albino variations can reach around USD 4,500 each (Prang 2020b). Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray seems to be rarely demanded by Asian markets and no reports of hybridization were identified in Asian countries.
country: Brazil

description: The Porcupine Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon histrix) is a small (to 52 cm disc width (DW)) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the ParanÃ¡-La Plata River Basin and distributed in a relatively limited geographic range (less than 4,000 km of river length) across Argentina, Brazil, and Paraguay. There is scarce information on its biology. Adult females ranged from 33â€“36 cm DW with fecundity varying between 6â€“9 pups per litter. Its intrinsic susceptibility to extinction was estimated to be lower when compared with other potamotrygonins. This species is rarely used for human consumption, and enters the international ornamental aquarium trade in limited numbers. The Porcupine Freshwater Stingray is mainly threatened by environmental impacts, mostly driven by agricultural development, with its entire range in one of the main agriculture areas for growing soybeans. Its range lies entirely within a major waterway of paramount economic importance, which may soon be further impacted by large infrastructure development. Therefore, the habitat of this species is under ongoing modification and may suffer from large-scale degradation. This species is also subject to urban development, bycatch, and negative fishery. Climate change effects that may alter the hydrological regime throughout its distribution area are of concern for this species. Considering the existing threats to which the species is subject and its biological features, a population reduction of at least >20% is suspected over the past three generation lengths (22 years). Therefore, this species is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2ce).
trade: The Porcupine Freshwater Stingray is rarely taken as a food source but is captured as bycatch in other fisheries. Given its small size, the species is rarely sought after for its meat but it is reported to be captured with harpoons (Soto et al. 2009). It may be taken as bycatch in longlines (for other stingrays, but also for other fishes, such as 'dorado', Salminus brasiliensis, and 'surubim', Pseudoplatystoma spp.), and in much smaller numbers in gillnets. Furthermore, the Porcupine Freshwater Stingray is an incidental catch by recreational fishers and often has its tail mutilated or is not released alive back to the river (negative fishery, sensu Compagno and Cook 1995).The Porcupine Freshwater Stingray is occasionally captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade but is taken in limited numbers (Ross and Schaffer 2000) and predominantly targeting only the more attractive dorsal color patterns. The name Potamotrygon histrix is commonly found in the international ornamental aquarium trade under the label â€œhistrixâ€ or â€œhystrixâ€, however, in most cases these names correspond to other species, such as Wallace's Freshwater Stingray (P. wallacei), Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (P. orbignyi), and YepÃ©zâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (P. yepezi) (Ross and Schaffer 2000, Prang 2020a), and also as False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (P. humerosa) and Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray (P. scobina). The "true histrix" (Porcupine Freshwater Stingray) is actually taken in limited numbers, with specimens reportedly sourced from Argentina (Prang 2020b). It has been illegally exported from Brazil (AraÃºjo et al. 2004).
cm_name: Arraia, Liba spari, Porcupine river stingray, Spar, Tjoeboela
country: Argentina, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Paraguay

description: The False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon humerosa) is a small (to 33 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater ray. It is endemic to Brazil where it has a patchy distribution and is mainly associated with the Amazon River's tributary confluence areas. It is a low fecundity species (average of two pups/litter), with a gestation period of 3â€“4 months and an annual reproductive cycle. The estimated generation length is 7.5 years. The False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray has been illegally traded in the international ornamental aquarium market, often under the name of other reticulated potamotrygonin species. Increasing tourism and urban development threaten the species due to habitat degradation and negative fishing. Bycatch is also a threat present in most areas of its distribution. These threats associated with its reproductive parameters led to a suspected population reduction of approximately 20% in the past three generations length (23 years) due to levels of exploitation, a decline in habitat quality, and pollutants. The causes of this population reduction are still increasing and conservation strategies remain lacking. The False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray is precautionarily assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cde).
trade: The False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray has been illegally exported from Brazil and is present in the international ornamental aquarium trade, sometimes under the names Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi) and Marques' Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon marquesi) (Ramos 2017, M.L.G. Araujo unpubl. data 2023). Approximately 10% of all Reticulate Freshwater Stingray specimens exported from ParÃ¡ corresponded to the False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (M.L.G. Araujo unpubl. data 2023). In the international ornamental aquarium trade, the False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray has been identified under the codes P061, R061 R062, R065, R066, R067, R063, R148 (Ross and Schaeffer 2000). The market price varies between USD$180/individual (European market) to USD$340/individual (USA market) (Prang 2020). There have been some trade codes incorrectly applied to the False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray, which actually correspond to other reticulated species such: Marques' Freshwater Stingray(or â€œMosaic Rayâ€, P46, R146), Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (R064) and Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon schroederi) (P10, R124). Likewise, False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray has also been misidentified as the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (R078, R081) and Marques' Freshwater Stingray (P23, R122).This species is only taken as a food source when other options are not available due to its relatively small size, however, there is a constant increasing tendency to have freshwater rays taken as food source throughout the Amazon Basin. Therefore, this species is used as food source but not as intensively as other potamotrygonins, such as Paratrygon species. Occasionally the species is taken for its liver oil, which is used as a traditional medicine mainly for respiratory diseases and birth deliveries (Rosa et al. 2010).
country: Brazil

description: The Pearl Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon jabuti) is a medium-sized (up to 55 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the tributaries of the upper to middle TapajÃ³s River in Brazil. The species' dorsal colour pattern makes it highly esteemed in the national and international ornamental aquarium trade. Adults have been illegally captured and traded in high numbers since the 1990s and this species has been estimated to account for 35% of the ornamental stingray seizures by the Brazilian Government between 2002 and 2018. The TapajÃ³s River basin region has also been severely affected by habitat degradation in recent decades driven by legal and illegal gold mining activities across almost 70% of the species range. These mining activities alter physicochemical habitat conditions such as turbidity and dissolved oxygen, and cause exposure to elemental mercury used in the extraction process. Moreover, agriculture expansion has led to deforestation and further habitat degradation pressure as it deteriorates environmental conditions by subjecting the species to pesticides and fertilizers runoff and water silting. Thus, considering the combined effects of exploitation levels and habitat degradation, it is suspected that the Pearl Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population reduction of at least 50% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) and therefore, is assessed as Endangered (A2cd).
trade: The Pearl Freshwater Stingray has been illegally captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade at least for the past three decades with the trade targeting mainly adult specimens ( â‰¥39 cm disc width). The species is one of the most valued species in the international ornamental aquarium trade due to its dorsal color pattern (AraÃºjo 2004). The trade code for this species is R080 and P54 with the trade common name Jabuti Pearl Ray (Ross and Schaeffer 2000).Â Juveniles of this endemic species have been illegally exported from Brazil as the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro) due to their similar ocellated dorsal color pattern. From 2003 to 2009, approximately 22,000 Pearl Freshwater Stingray specimens were illicitly exported from Brazil (AraÃºjo 2004, M.L.G. AraÃºjo unpubl. data 2022). It has been estimated that the Pearl Freshwater Stingray accounted for 35% of the stingrays seized by the Brazilian Government between 2002 and 2018 (Prang 2020). Currently, the species continues to be illegally exported (approximately 1,000â€“1,500 individuals per year) for captive breeding mainly in Asian and European facilities, including for the breeding of attractive hybrid color patterns. Female stingrays exported from Brazil to Asian countries have been used to produce hybrids withÂ  Ocellate Freshwater Stingray, Tapajos Freshwater Stingray (P. albimaculata), Marquesâ€™ Freshwater Stingray (P. marquesi), and Xingu Freshwater Stingray (P. leopoldi) (M.L.G. AraÃºjo unpubl. data 2022). This is why, despite being endemic to Brazil, Thailand exports approximately 3,500 individuals per year from captive breeding facilities (Prang 2020).
country: Brazil

description: The Xingu Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon leopoldi) is a medium-sized (to 72 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the Xingu River basin in Brazil. It is known only from freshwater habitats and in the Xingu River clearwater basin there is predominance of dark basaltic rocky substrates alternating with sandy stretches and river rapids. The species' dorsal colour pattern makes it highly valued in the international ornamental aquarium trade. Juveniles are captured for the ornamental trade, while adults have been increasingly captured for human consumption or are subject to persecution in some areas due to fear of sting injuries. The Xingu River basin region has been severely impacted by habitat degradation and fragmentation in the past two decades due to the construction of a dam in the mid-Xingu River, with plans to build other upstream impoundments, and legal and illegal mining, agricultural and livestock activities, deforestation, and climate change. A Brazilian ornamental trade quota system was established in 2003 for the Xingu Freshwater Stingray to regulate the ornamental exports from Brazil; however, weak compliance and enforcement has led to ongoing illegal captures. Despite being bred in captivity mainly in the Asian region to generate more valuable hybrid colour patterns, the demand for wild-caught specimens has not ceased. This species has some refuge from fishing pressure in limited parts of its range in environmental protected areas, mainly in headwater regions. A demographic analysis considering population structure, growth parameters, and mortality estimated at least a 60% reduction in the population over the past three generation lengths (21 years). While many parts of the species' range are subject to environmental and anthropogenic threats, the demographic analysis considered that the entire range was exposed to these threats, whereas the species has refuge in some areas. Thus, it is inferred that the Xingu Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation and increasing and significant habitat degradation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable (VU A2bcd).
trade: The species is considered of high commercial value in the international ornamental aquarium trade (Araujo et al. 2004a, Charvet-Almeida 2006, Ramos et al. 2015). It is also used for human consumption with an increase in the captures of adult specimens for human consumption (Charvet-Almeida 2006), which are also being sold in regional restaurants (Y. Torres and P. Charvet pers. obs. 2021). Occasionally, the Xingu Freshwater Stingray is used for folklore medicinal purposes (mainly liver oil) (Charvet-Almeida 2006). The stings are regionally used by indigenous native populations as decoration elements. The traditional use of stings as combs to remove lice and lice eggs has also been observed. Stings have also been used as a negative element in regional religious rituals (Y. Torres and P. Charvet pers. obs. 2021).
country: Brazil

description: The Madeira Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon limai) is a medium-sized (to 66 cm disc width) freshwater stingray endemic to the Amazon River basin, where it has been recorded only from the upper Madeira River basin, at Jamari River, in an area associated with the Samuel Hydroelectric Dam. A significant decline has been observed in population numbers of this species and fish diversity has also declined in the basin following the construction of the dam and associated forest conversion to grazing pasture, due to soil and water contamination. Fishing is not a threat to this species, as most of the fisheries of this area have been moved to the upper reaches of the Dam and fishers do not capture this species. Taking a precautionary approach, which considers the recent drastic declines in habitat quality in its range, it is suspected that the Madeira Freshwater StingrayÂ has undergone a population reduction of 20â€“29% over the past three generation lengths (33 years) due to a decline in habitat quality, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2bc).
trade: The use and trade patterns of this species are unknown.
country: Brazil

description: The Magdalena Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon magdalenae) is a small (to 48 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the Magdalena-Cauca and Atrato basins in northern Colombia. It is known only from freshwater habitats. It is heavily fished for the national and international ornamental aquarium trade, being one of the most highly traded freshwater rays from Colombia with juveniles captured for the ornamental trade. Adults are targeted and taken incidentally for human consumption. The Magdalena-Cauca and Atrato basins region has been severely impacted by habitat degradation and fragmentation in the past four decades due to dam construction, agricultural activities, deforestation, mining, and drying up of swamps and hydrological changes. Genetic population structure is apparent throughout the speciesâ€™ range with the presence of geographic barriers that could isolate populations and decrease the resilience of the species. Thus, it is suspected that the Magdalena Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 20â€“29% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) due to levels of exploitation and significant habitat degradation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened, close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd.
trade: The Magdalena Freshwater Stingray is valued in the national and international ornamental aquarium trade and between 2003â€“2012 was the first or second most exported Potamotrygon species in Colombia (SÃ¡nchez-Duarte et al. 2013). Juveniles of this species are mostly used in the ornamental trade. Traders consider that there are two morphs (red and black) of the species in the Magdalena basin, but only the black ones (lower basin) are of interest for the ornamental trade. The meat of adults is also used for human consumption, although consumption is occasional, local, and mainly in the upper basin (i.e., Betania reservoir) (MejÃ­a-Falla et al. 2016). At some times of the year when fishing for other species is very low, adults of the Magdalena Freshwater Stingray are captured for subsistence use (Lasso et al. 2012, Mojica et al. 2012).
cm_name: Magdalena freshwater stingray, Magdalena river stingray
country: Colombia

description: Marques' Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon marquesi) is a medium-size (up to 59 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray with a possible patchy distribution across some of the SolimÃµes-Amazonas System tributaries. This species is found predominantly in muddy substrates, and is also considered to be territorial and sedentary. Marquesâ€™ Freshwater Stingray exhibits a low fecundity (average 2â€“3 pups per litter). It is caught as bycatch by demersal longline and shrimp trawl and has been illegally exported to the international ornamental aquarium trade since the 1990s. Habitat degradation caused by damming, dredging, deforestation, salinization, and buffalo farms are threats for this species. Populations have been suspected to have undergone a reduction of at least 20â€“25% over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Hence, Marques' Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Near Threatened A2cd.
trade: Juvenile, subadult, and adult individuals of Marquesâ€™ Freshwater Stingray are targeted for the international ornamental trade. This species has been common in the international ornamental trade, being illegally exported since the late 1990s, mainly from Brazil (export centres include ParÃ¡, CearÃ¡ and Pernambuco states) and Peru (M.L.G. AraÃºjo and P. Charvet pers. comm. 2024). In the international ornamental aquarium trade, it has been misidentified as False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray or Marble Ray (Potamotrygon humerosa), Ocellate River Stingray or Mantilla Ray (P. motoro), Reticulate Freshwater Stingray or Mosaic Ray (P. orbignyi) and Potamotrygon sp. (Ross and SchÃ¤fer 2000). The reference codes (P-numbers system) for P. marquesi are P-08, P-19, P-20, P-21, P-22, P-24 (named â€œMarbel or Mantillaâ€); P-23, P-46 (named â€œMosaic Rayâ€) (Ross and Schaeffer 2000, Prang 2020). In the last ten years, it has been used to produce hybrid individuals with Pearl Freshwater Stingray (P. jabuti), Xingu Freshwater Stingray (P. leopoldi) and Ocellate River Stingray (P. motoro) (Prang 2020). In ParÃ¡ State, ornamental captures are concentrated in Cachoeira do Arari (MarajÃ³ Island, ParÃ¡ State) Brazil (Almeida 2008, M.L.G. Araujo unpubl. data 2024). Between 2008â€“2014, many Marquesâ€™ Freshwater Stingray were exported from Brazil under the name of Reticulate Freshwater Stingray or Mosaic Ray (P. orbignyi) (Prang 2020). During this period the number of individuals bred in captivity and the number of hybrids of this species increased in the international ornamental fish market. In AmapÃ¡ State, this species is not commonly used for ornamental trade or local food, however, it is captured as bycatch in shrimp and gillnets fisheries (Gama 2013, Gama and Rosa 2015). In Acre State, Marquesâ€™ Freshwater Stingray individuals are accidentally caught in gillnet subsistence fisheries and usually are discarded dead (S.V. Melo, person. comm. 2021). In the MarajÃ³ Island, it is occassionally taken for food whenever other better options are unavailable (P. Charvet pers. comm. 2024).

description: The Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro) is a small to medium sized (to 60 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray. It is the most widespread Neotropical freshwater stingray and occurs in several of the main South American river basins, including the Amazon, Orinoco, Essequibo, Tocantins-Araguaia, XingÃº, TapajÃ³s, Madeira basins and ParanÃ¡-La Plata regions. Moreover, this species was taken to Southeast Asia by the international ornamental aquarium trade, was released or escaped to wild habitats and became an invasive species in Indonesia and Singapore. In its natural habitat this species has an annual reproductive cycle and an average of 7 pups per litter. This species is targeted for human consumption and international ornamental trade purposes, and also subject to negative fishing. Similarly to other freshwater stingrays, this species is also exposed to several habitat degradation threats across its range. The fishing pressure and habitat degradation in some regions has led to some potential localised population declines, while in other areas the population is considered stable. However, due to its widespread distribution, only slight levels of overall population reduction of ~10â€“19% over the past three generation lengths (29 years) are suspected. Therefore, the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Least Concern.
trade: The Ocellate Freshwater Stingray is targeted for consumption, being one of the most captured species in commercial fishing throughout the Amazon River and most major tributaries across the Amazon Basin. It is captured by different gears, mostly longline and seine nets, but also by trawling and spearing. Adult and subadult individuals predominate in catch composition. Captured fish are usually traded in Brazilian fish markets within the Amazon Region but are also taken to be traded as far as the southeast portions of Brazil, sometimes as marine skates and other Rajiformes (Camacho-Oliveira et al. 2020). This species has been exported to Asia (mainly Japan and South Korea) as Rajiformes, both as dried and frozen fillets (Araujo 2004, Charvet et al. 2022, Oliveira et al. 2023). Furthermore, the species is a target for the international ornamental aquarium trade, representing the most exported potamotrygonin species for ornamental purposes from Brazil (Duncan et al. 2010) and Colombia (Lasso et al. 2013). The species is identified in the ornamental market by the following codes: P1, P2, P3, P5, P32, P33, P34, P35, P36, P37, P38, P39, P40, P41, P44, P45, P46, P47, P48, P49 (Ross and Schaffer 2000). Furthermore, the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray is a target species for the production of hybrids with other potamotrygonin species, including Xingu Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon leopoldi), Pearl Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon jabuti), and Wallace's Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon wallacei) (Prang 2020a).
country: Argentina, Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana [FR], Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, Singapore, Suriname, Thailand, Uruguay, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of)

description: The MarajÃ³ Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon ocellata) is a rare and poorly-known Neotropical freshwater stingray that is currently considered endemic to Brazil. Only two specimens have been collected, and the holotype was lost during World War II, so there is only one specimen available. Its distribution is highly restricted as it is only known from two locations at the mouth of the Amazon River between ParÃ¡ and AmapÃ¡ states. Its maximum size is unknown since no adults have yet been reported and its biology remains unknown. Since the last Red List assessment, the uncertainty about its taxonomic validity persists, due to similarities with other species and only two records. Consequently, the speciesâ€™ potential full range and threats are undefined but its known range of occurrence comprises the very dynamic and habitat and fisheries impacted Amazon Estuary region. Its presence in the international ornamental aquarium trade or use for human consumption is unclear. However, it has a similar dorsal colour pattern to the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (P. motoro) and thus may be captured and traded under that species name. Therefore, due to taxonomic uncertainty and since it is unknown if the fishing pressure or threats to habitat quality are causing a population reduction, there is currently inadequate information to assess the MarajÃ³ Freshwater Stingray beyond Data Deficient.
trade: There is no reported use of this species for the international ornamental aquarium trade or human consumption.
country: Brazil

description: The Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi) is small to medium sized (61 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray. It occurs in northern South America, in Amazon River tributaries, and in the Orinoco, Essequibo, Approuague, Surinam and Parnaiba River basins. The species has an annual reproductive cycle and low fecundity (average of two pups per litter). The Reticulate Freshwater Stingray is not among the highly targeted and valued species in the international ornamental aquarium trade but there is an ongoing demand for it. The main threat for this species is bycatch and negative fishing, mainly associated with fishing operations and tourism. As other Potamotrygonins, this species is subject to various habitat degradation threats in part of its range. Nevertheless, considering that this is a widely distributed species with the population in most of its range considered stable or not severely affected by fishing pressure, the population is suspected to have undergone a reduction of ~10â€“19% over the past three generation lengths (35 years), and the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Least Concern.
trade: The Reticulate Freshwater Stingray is mainly captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade. The trade codes used for the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray are P11, R043, R073, R074, R075, R076, R077, R082 (Ross and Schaffer 2000). It has been noted that some that trade codes under other species names also correspond to the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray such as: P. dumerilii (synonym of Reticulate Freshwater Stingray) (P09, R071, P42, R072, P47, R068); False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (P. humerosa) (R064); Raspy River Stingray (P. scobina) (P7, R105), Schroeder's Freshwater Stingray (P. schroederi) (P040, P045, R028, R145), Maracaibo River Stingray (P. yepezi) (R59), Potamotrygon cf. yepezi (R55, R60, R140) and Potamotrygon sp. (P43, R029) (Prang 2020b). Between 2000â€“2006, it was reported that 74,961 individuals were exported from Colombia (Lasso et al. 2013). From Brazil, between 2003 and 2005, a total of 2,827 Reticulate Freshwater Stingray specimens were exported and then from 2008â€“2016, a total of 315 specimens were exported (Ramos 2017). According to the CITES trade database, in 2018, 6,100 Reticulate Freshwater Stingray individuals were exported with Brazil noted as the country of origin (CITES 2018), however, very probably these 2018 exports did not correspond entirely to the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray.There are some endemic species (i.e., Marque's Freshwater Stingray (P. marquesi) and juvenile specimens of TapajÃ³s Freshwater Stingray (P. albimaculata) that have their export prohibited but which have been exported as the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Ramos 2017, Prang 2020a). The Reticulate Freshwater Stingray has been indicated as a subsistence source of food (Lasso et al. 2013) and in some regions can be occasionally taken for consumption (Charvet-Almeida 2001).
country: Brazil, Colombia

description: The Pantanal Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon pantanensis) is a small to medium-sized (to 34 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the Pantanal Ecoregion in Brazil, Paraguay, andÂ BolÃ­via. It has a discontinued distribution in the Paraguay River basin and in part of the GuaporÃ© River. It is estimated to have a relatively short generation length of 7.5 years. Population sizes are possibly small. Habitat degradation, loss and fragmentation related to urbanization, farming, and pollutants pose major threats to this species. The Pantanal Freshwater Stingray has a relatively restricted distribution and has been subject to severe habitat alteration and degradation, and loss due to forest fires related to anthropogenic actions and climate change in the last few years and thus, a population reduction of at least 30% is suspected over the past three generation lengths (23 years). Hence, the Pantanal Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Vulnerable A2ce.
trade: This species belongs to the Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro) and Amanda's Freshwater Stingray (P. amandae) group. It is occasionally captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade and is traded mainly under the name Ocellate Freshwater Stingray. Further details on trade and use are required.
country: Bolivia (Plurinational State of), Brazil, Paraguay

description: The Great Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon rex) is a medium-sized (to 69 cm disc width) freshwater stingray endemic to the Tocantins River, Brazil. It has a low fecundity (three pups per litter) and is a caught as bycatch in small-scale subsistence and artisanal fisheries with a range of gears including gillnets and longlines. It is not retained for consumption but is often persecuted due to stinging accidents with humans (negative interactions), with the tails cut off or it is killed before being discarded back into the river. It is occasionally found in the international ornamental aquarium trade. The species is also subject to habitat loss and degradation due to the construction of five medium to large hydroelectric dams along the Tocantins River over the past five decades, which may result in fragmentation of populations of the Great Freshwater Stingray and degraded the water quality. There is no population trend information available but the fishing pressure, habitat degradation, and population fragmentation are very likely to be causing some level of population reduction. Thus, it is suspected that the Great Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population reduction of approximately 20â€“29% over the past three generation lengths (33 years) due to declines in habitat quality and levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Near Threatened (close to meeting Vulnerable A2cd).
trade: This species is occasionally found in the international ornamental aquarium trade.
country: Brazil

description: Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon schroederi) is a medium-sized (to 60 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater ray from the Amazon Basin region, mainly in the upper-mid Negro River basin (Brazil) and in the upper-mid Orinoco River basin (Venezuela, Colombia). Although reasonably widespread within its known range, it is not a common species. The species has a low fecundity (average of two embryos) with an annual reproductive cycle. It is present in the ornamental fish trade, however, is not one of the most traded due to its high mortality rates once removed from the wild. Habitat degradation occurs throughout its range mainly by sand dredging and gold mining, which introduces pollutants that affect this species. The increase of tourist activities has led to a rise in negative fishery, also posing a threat for Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray. Considering its habitat specificity, life history characteristics, intense ornamental capture in at least part of its range, and habitat degradation and pollutants, Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is suspected to undergone at least a 30% population reduction in the past three generation lengths (24years). Therefore, it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cde.
trade: Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is an ornamental species of freshwater stingray with a flower-like dorsal colour pattern and for this it is also referred to as â€œFlower Rayâ€, or â€œRosette Flower Rayâ€. Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray and Tiger Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon tigrina) are known to form a dorsal colour pattern group known as â€œRosettes Raysâ€ (Prang 2020). In the ornamental trade, the species is often misidentified as False Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon humerosa) (P10), Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro) (P04, R128) and Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi) (Trade codes P04, P40, P45, R128, R145, respectively). The trade code for Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray corresponds to R151 (Ross and Schaffer 2000).Mainly juveniles and subadults are captured (AraÃºjo et al. 2005, Lasso et al. 2013). Despite being valued in the international ornamental aquarium trade, the post-capture mortality of the species throughout the productive chain is extremely high (~80% of all captured individuals) making it less attractive for commercialization (AraÃºjoÂ et al. 2005). In Colombia, Schroederâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is the third most exported species. However, a large part of the records from the InÃ­rida Region (Colombia) corresponds to individuals from Venezuela which are illegally exported to Colombia (Lasso and SÃ¡nchez-Duarte 2012, Lasso et al. 2013). Germany is the primary ornamental importer of this species (AraÃºjo et al. 2005, Lasso et al. 2013). In some Asian countries, this species is bred to produce hybrids with black dorsal colour patterned stingrays, such as Xingu Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon leopoldi) (M.L.G. AraÃºjo unpubl. data 2023). There are no reports of this species being fished for human consumption.
country: Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of)

description: The Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon scobina) is a medium-sized to large (to 69 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray with a confirmed distribution range in the white waters of the Amazon River channel and lower section of some of its main tributaries in Brazil, present mainly in its lower portion and in the Amazon Estuary. It is also possibly extant in the mid Orinoco River drainage in Colombia and Venezuala. Part of its range is influenced by seasonal salinity variations and it seems to tolerate some levels of salinity in its habitat. The Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray has sexual dimorphism and sexual and ontogenetic segregation have been observed. Fecundity varies between 1â€“16 (average 6) pups per litter, and it has a yearly reproductive cycle associated with the hydrological cycle. The Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray is targeted by artisanal fisheries for human consumption in parts of its distribution range, is taken as bycatch throughout its area of occurrence, is captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade, and has its liver oil extracted for regional medicinal purposes. This species is subject to a combination of threats that comprise fisheries for consumption, bycatch captures, and ornamental and negative fisheries. Environmental degradation, habitat reduction, and climate change effects are also considered threats for this species. Since the Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray has been often captured for human consumption in its core distribution area in the lower section of the Amazon drainage, and is subject to environmental impacts throughout its distribution range, a population reduction of at least 25% is suspected over the past three generation lengths (32 years). Therefore, the Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2cde).
trade: The Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray is targeted by artisanal fisheries (mainly longlines) for human consumption in parts of its distribution range (mainly in the MarajÃ³ Bay and lower Amazon River area) and is taken as bycatch (mainly nets) throughout its distribution range. It is also captured to be traded in the international ornamental aquarium market, has its liver oil extracted for regional medicinal purposes, and sting used in religious rituals.Â The Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray was reported as one of the main stingrays captured in Amazon Basin for consumption along with Discus Stingray (Paratrygon aiereba), Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon motoro), and Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi) (Ramos 2017). In the Amazon River mouth region (mainly MarajÃ³ Bay) this species is intensively captured as a food source, both for subsistence and to be traded in regional fish markets, to be prepared as a fish stew or fried (Charvet-Almeida 2001).Â Along with ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon falkneri), the Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray is marketed mainly in European countries but dorsal color patterns of ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray are more valued since they more closely resemble Reticulate Freshwater Stingray patterns (Prang 2020). Some of the common names applied to this species in the international ornamental aquarium trade include: Picasso Stingray (P41, mainly in the USA market), BelÃ©m Ray (P7, Europe and mainly in Czechia and Germany), and Scobina Ray (P7, Europe and mainly in the Netherlands) (Ross and Schaffer 2000, Prang 2020). Juvenile specimens of Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray are commercialized under the name â€˜Potamotrygon reticulataâ€™ (= P. orbignyi) (Prang 2020). This species has also been reported as exported from Peru (SanchÃ©z-Duarte et al. 2013). Exported species for the international aquarium trade reported as P. castexi (which has been synonymized with P. falkneri), traded under the names â€˜Tigrinusâ€™ andÂ  â€˜Tigrilloâ€™ (trade codes P31 and R055), possibly correspond to Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray, ParanÃ¡ Freshwater Stingray and Tatiana's Freshwater Stingray (P. tatianae) (Prang 2020).The use of liver oil as a medicinal resource (e.g., to treat respiratory diseases, facilitate labor) has been documented in the lower Amazon River region (Charvet-Almeida 2001). Stings are kept to be used as a negative element in religious rituals and have also been recorded to remove hair lice (Charvet-Almeida 2001, Charvet et al. 2024).
country: Brazil, Colombia

description: The ParnaÃ­ba Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon signata) is a small to medium-sized (up to 60 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the ParnaÃ­ba River drainage, a semi-arid region in Northeastern Brazil, where most rivers are intermittent. Population and life history data are limited for this species. The main threats to this species include negative fishing pressure and bycatch. It is occasionally present in the international ornamental aquarium trade. Environmental impacts comprise erosion, silting, pollutants, and changes of water regime in rivers, due to damming, agricultural and urban expansion. Severe droughts, probably exacerbated by global climate change, tend to reduce and further restrict the species habitat in intermittent rivers. The ParnaÃ­ba Freshwater Stingray has a patchy area of distribution with a seasonal variation in a single river drainage in a semi-arid region, which is isolated from other river basins. The ParnaÃ­ba River drainage is subject to extreme fluctuations in hydrological cycle,Â possibly enhanced by climate change effects, within the species distribution range with overall reductions in freshwater flow of major tributaries (as high as 49â€“68%) observed over an approximately 50 year period. Exploitation and declines in habitat quality, including pollutants, lead to a suspected population reduction of at least 40% over the past three generation lengths (23 years). Thus, the Parnaiba Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Vulnerable A2cde.
trade: The ParnaÃ­ba Freshwater Stingray fisheries are mainly incidental or correspond to negative fisheries (sensu Compagno and Cook 1995). Nevertheless, when captured, at least the stings and liver are often removed to be used (Moro and Rosa 2016). The local use of liver oil to treat rheumatic diseases and respiratory problems has been documented (Moro et al. 2016). The sting is sold in local markets with different applications by the local community (e.g., arrowheads and regional rituals) (Moro and Rosa 2016).Â The human consumption of its meat is rare, but can be found in the trade when more valued fish options are not available.Â It is occasionally captured and observed in the international ornamental fish trade (Ross and Schaeffer 2000, AraÃºjo et al. 2004). There are other Potamotrygon species sold under the name of ParnaÃ­ba Freshwater Stingray, such as Whitespotted Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon scobina) (trade codes P41, R141, S66127, R108, S66093-4) and Potamotrygon spp. (trade codes R107, S66081-4, P48, R109, S66094) (Prang 2020).
country: Brazil

description: Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon wallacei) is a small (up to 31 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray endemic to the Negro River basin in Brazil. It has high site fidelity to its preferred leafy substrate habitats in shallow acid waters with low oxygen levels. It is subject to fishing pressure for the international ornamental aquarium trade and to persecution in some of its distribution range due to fear of sting injuries. In 2015â€“2016, deforestation and forest fires events occurred in the region with the highest population density of this species and severely impacted the populations. This led to an observed reduction in maximum disc width size and age with a concurrent reduction in generation length from 5 years to 3.5 years. Therefore, it is suspected that the Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray has undergone a population decline of at least 66% over the past three generation lengths (11 years) due to exploitation and habitat degradation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2cd.
trade: Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray has a brownish dorsal colour pattern and is not as valued as some other freshwater stingray (e.g., Xingu Freshwater Stingray Potamotrygon leopoldi, Henleâ€™s Freshwater Stingray Potamotrygon henlei). Nonetheless, its small size makes it very attractive to aquarium hobbyists with limited-sized tanks. It is also considered a difficult species to breed in captivity and hence of less interest to the Asian ornamental trade (AraÃºjo 2020). The species has a high socioeconomic importance for fishers in the Barcelos region since the purchase of Amazonian ornamental fish usually follows a joint sales model (AraÃºjo et al. 2005). In essence, if the exporter cannot provide an item of the order list (e.g., stingray), the whole negotiation may be called off for the more profitable and valuable species exported from the State of Amazonas (such as the Cardinal Tetra, Paracheirodon axelrodi) (AraÃºjo et al. 2005). So, despite not being highly desired by the ornamental market, due to this joint sales model, Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray is the main freshwater stingray species exported in the Amazon State in Brazil (AraÃºjo 1998).Â According to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) records, the main markets for the species are Germany, the United States, Japan, Taiwan, and the south-eastern states of Brazil (AraÃºjo 2020). The Brazilian export quota policy introduced for this species in 2008 allowed it to be valued in the international ornamental fish market, and due to this, exporters from countries like Peru and Colombia started using the label â€œPotamotrygon hystrixâ€ or â€œColombian Hystrixâ€ (referring to Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray). However, these exports actually refer to the Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi). Therefore, when purchasing â€œhystrix,â€ importers are led to believe that they are buying Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray (known in the market as â€œTrue Hystrixâ€). Perhaps due to this confusion, in the CITES freshwater stingray export records, Peru and Colombia appear as exporting countries of Wallaceâ€™s Freshwater Stingray alongside Brazil (AraÃºjo 2020). There is no report of consumption of this species.
country: Brazil

description: FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon yepezi) is a small to medium-sized (to 48 cm disc width) Neotropical freshwater stingray that occurs in the Maracaibo Lake (Lago de Maracaibo) hydrographic basin, in northwest Venezuela and in northeast Colombia. This is considered a low abundance and altitudinally limited species. It is a low fecundity species (average three pups per litter). FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray has been considered overfished since it is taken as a food source locally, regionally, and is exported, is captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade, and for its liver oil used for medicinal purposes. This species is subject to a wide variety of threats, including fisheries (consumption, bycatch, ornamental, negative), habitat loss and degradation from several sources, agricultural expansion, industrial and urban development, disruption of hydrological regime, water demand, salinization, oil spills, climate change effects, and introduction of non-native and alien species. Thus, considering that this species has been subject to overfishing, various and intense habitat degradation caused by anthropogenic-based activities in its core distribution range, a population reduction of at least 60% is inferred over the past three generation lengths (29 years). Therefore,Â FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray is assessed as Endangered (EN A2cde).
trade: FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray is taken for human consumption locally, regionally, and is exported. It is also captured for the international ornamental aquarium trade and its liver oil is used for medicinal purposes.It is a species of interest in the Maracaibo Lake Basin, being one of the stingray species vital for subsistence, commercial, and ornamental fishing and trade (Lasso et al. 2013, O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡ unpub. data). Artisanal fisheries capture 90% of the overall stingray catches in Lake Maracaibo. Between 2010â€“2019, the catches reported for the three stingray species (FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray, Longnose Stingray (Hypanus guttatus) and Atlantic Chupare (Styracura schmardae)) landed in the 13 main ports of the Maracaibo Lake totalled 1,088 mt. Notably, the catch increased significantly from a minimum of 3.6 mt in 2016 to a maximum of 380 mt in 2019. These rays were observed to be sold in local, national (Venezuela), and international markets, including Colombia and Asian countries (O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡ unpub. data).In southern Maracaibo Lake, subsistence fishing yields monthly catches of stingrays, including FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray, ranging from 20 to 30 kg. This fishing method accounts for about 10% of the total catch for these species. The stingrays are caught in lagoons and streams using small, motorless wooden boats called â€˜cayucosâ€™. The artisanal fishing fleet operates daily along the coasts and river mouths of Maracaibo Lake, including mangrove lagoons and wetlands in the south. Commercial stingray fishing occurs in the Maracaibo Lake and its tributaries using wood and fiberglass boats powered by 40 HP outboard motors, locally named 'chalanas'. The main commercial fishing gear are the â€˜chinchorrosâ€™, or nets with mesh openings of 6.4 to 11.4 cm and shrimp hamlets (â€˜mandingasâ€™) with openings of 1.3 to 2 cm.Â Official records and unpublished observations specifically of FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray fishery in the Maracaibo Lake basin show that average annual catches were 38 mt per year from 1983 to 1989, rising to 463 mt per year from 1990 to 1999. Between 2000 and 2009, catches nearly doubled to 837 mt per year. This fishery has become a vital socio-economic activity in the region, leading to the processing and commercialization of its meat in retail and wholesale markets, including supermarkets. The fishing and trade of FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray are culturally and nutritionally important, as they support the preparation of traditional dishes like "mojito," a popular meal in towns and communities near Maracaibo Lake (O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡, unpub. data).Despite not being a highly valued species in the international ornamental aquarium trade, the importance of the FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray as an ornamental species has been reported by several authors (Lasso et al. 2013). The species is targeted to some extent and fishing methods comprise hand nets, beach nets, nylon lines with hooks, and cast nets using earthworms as bait (Lasso et al. 2013). Between 2005 and 2007, FernÃ¡ndez-YÃ©pez's Freshwater Stingray was heavily captured in the CachirÃ­ (sub-basin of the LimÃ³n River) and Palmar Rivers, primarily at night during the dry and low water season, using flashlights and cast nets. Since the mid-1980s, Venezuela has had a market for this species in the ornamental aquarium trade, with prices ranging from USD 4â€“4.50 per individual (8â€“12 cm DW) (Lasso 2006). In 2013, the domestic price was 250 Bs.F (~USD 0.83) (Lasso et al. 2013), however, it is more valued internationally, mainly by specialized distributors and collectors in North America, Europe, and Asia (O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡ unpub. data). In 2006, a Venezuelan company exported specimens to Germany and Japan, with sizes ranging from 12â€“45 cm DW, priced between USD 20 and USD 60 each (O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡, unpub. data). It is important to note that the commercialization of this species as an ornamental fish is illegal under Venezuelan regulations (O. Lasso-AlcalÃ¡ unpub.data). In Colombia, this species is sometimes caught in subsistence fisheries in the mid-lower Catatumbo River Basin and is valued for its medicinal use, particularly the liver oil for treating asthma (Lasso et al. 2013). In Puerto Santander, it is occasionally captured for the ornamental trade, but in low numbers possibly due to low population abundance (Lasso et al. 2013).
country: Colombia, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of)

description: The Blue Shark (Prionace glauca) is a large (to 380 cm TL) oceanic pelagic shark wide-ranging throughout tropical and temperate waters from the surface down to 1,000 m deep. The species has the highest known population growth rates among pelagic sharks; it matures young and has large litters. It is caught globally as target and bycatch in commercial and small-scale pelagic longline, purse seine, and gillnet fisheries, although most of the take is bycatch of industrial pelagic fleets in offshore and high-seas waters. Generally, Blue Sharks are retained for the fins, although the demand for meat is likely increasing. The steepest population declines have occurred in the North and South Atlantic, with lesser declines in the Indian Ocean, and increases in the Pacific. The weighted global population trend estimated a median decline of 7.3%, with the highest probability of <20% reduction over three generation lengths (30â€“31.5 years). However, due to uncertainty in some of the regional estimated trends, inferred steep historic declines in the Mediterranean Sea, high levels of unregulated exploitation, and high levels of international trade in meat and fins, experts estimated a global population reduction of 20â€“29% over three generation and the Blue Shark is assessed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting Vulnerable A2bd).
trade: The Blue Shark is the most prevelent species in the shark fin trade. It comprises the majority of shark fins imported in Hong Kong; 17.3% in 1991â€“2001 and 49% in 2014 (Clarke et al. 2006a, Fields et al. 2018). The meat is often discarded but demand may be increasing and it is used in some regions where it is sold fresh locally and frozen or dried for international trade (Ebert et al.Â 2013, Dent and Clarke 2015).
