description: The Dwarf Sawfish (Pristis clavata) is a large (to at least 318 cm total length) estuarine and coastal shark-like ray. Historically, it was found widely across the Indoâ€“West Pacific, but it is now â€˜possibly extinctâ€™ throughout its east Indian and Southeast Asian range, and is now only extant in Papua Province (Indonesia), Papua New Guinea, and northern Australia. It occurs in inshore shallow waters of 0â€“20 m depth, with juveniles occurring within estuaries, while adults are thought to mainly use coastal environments.It is taken as bycatch (and was historically targeted) in commercial and small-scale fisheries and often retained for its meat and fins. Historically, its fins were considered among the most highly valued in the shark fin trade. This drove demand and increased exploitation of the species over the past decades. Habitat loss and the morphology of the rostrum, which makes them susceptible to capture in fishing gear, have also driven declines independently of trade. International trade of all sawfish species was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 with their listing on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), however, illegal trade continues (especially for their rostra, but in some regions also for their meat and fins). Throughout most of its range, this species is exposed to moderate to heavy fishing pressure, while habitat degradation has likely also impacted populations.Population declines are evident and likely severe in Papua Province (Indonesia) and Papua New Guinea, primarily due to intense gillnet fisheries pressure in estuaries and coastal areas. It is suspected that substantial declines in Dwarf Sawfish populations across all of northern Australia occurred prior to the 2000s. While population decline over the last three generations (63 years) is inferred for Western Australia and the Northern Territory, in recent years stabilization of declines or some recovery is likely to have occurred owing to reductions in fishing effort and spatial protections. Currently, the Kimberley region of Western Australia appears to be the most significant refuge for this species globally, due to spatial protections, extremely low commercial fishing activity, and low human population density. Within the last three generation lengths (63 years), declines are likely to still be ongoing throughout the Gulf of Carpentaria, particularly in Queensland, and it is likely that remnant populations of Dwarf Sawfish on the east coast of Queensland have almost depleted to local extinction. The species is likely extinct in east India, Malaysia, and western Indonesia, but it is not possible to determine the timing of possible extinction or that there are no remnant undetected populations and as such, it is suspected that steep population reductions have occurred in the western part of its historic range within the past three generation lengths (63 years). In its extant range in Papua Province (Indonesia), Papua New Guinea, and Australia, a population reduction of 70â€“75% is inferred over the past three generation lengths. Taken together, it is suspected that the Dwarf Sawfish has undergone a population reduction of >80% over the last three generation lengths (63 years) due to exploitation, habitat degradation, and reductions in extent of occurrence, and it is assessed as Critically Endangered (CR A2cd).
trade: The Dwarf Sawfish is likely to be retained when caught for consumption or for sale of the meat, fins, and rostra (except in Australia) (e.g., White et al. 2017a, Grant et al. 2021a, Grant et al. 2021b). Some communities in Papua New Guinea retain sawfish for cultural reasons, and rostra are routinely observed in houses of fishers for decorative purposes (Grant et al. 2021b). Anecdotal observations of rostra being sold in markets in Port Moresby indicate there is a domestic market for rostra, although no further information is available, and it is not considered that domestic trade of rostra is widespread (Grant et al. 2021a). Fins from sawfishes are sold to local fin buyers, and observations of legal and illegal market chains in southern Papua New Guinea indicate that fins likely enter global fin markets in East Asia (Busilacchi et al. 2021). Similarly, in Papua Province, Indonesia, this species is likely retained for consumption or sale of meat, fins, and rostra. There is presently no information on cultural uses and values of sawfishes in Papua Province.The Dwarf Sawfish has been protected in Australia since 2009, prohibiting any use or trade. Although ongoing retention of rostra still occurs, no data are available on the quantities. Prior to its national protection, the species was retained for sale of meat and fins, although this is not considered to currently occur on a large scale. Some Indigenous communities across northern Australia use sawfish for consumption and cultural purposes (e.g., McDavitt 2005). No data are available on the Indigenous catch; however, it is suspected to be localized, opportunistic, and low in volume (Kyne et al. 2013).
country: Australia, Papua New Guinea

description: The Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata) is a large (to 500 cm stretched total length) euryhaline shark-like ray with a widespread circumtropical distribution in the Atlantic Ocean with some population structure between the western and eastern Atlantic. The species occurs at depths of 0â€“122 m with juveniles occupying estuarine habitats and adults occurring in both estuarine and coastal waters. It is taken as bycatch (and was historically targeted) in commercial and small-scale fisheries, and often retained for its meat and fins. Historically, its fins were considered among the most highly valued in the shark fin trade, and this high value drove demand and increased exploitation of the species over the past decades. Habitat loss and the morphology of the rostrum, which makes them susceptible to capture in fishing gear, have also driven declines independently of trade. International trade of all sawfish species was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 with their listing on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), however, illegal trade continues (especially for their rostra, but in some areas also for their meat and fins). The species is also listed on Appendix 1 of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS), which prohibits the taking of the species. Both the western and eastern Atlantic populations have undergone severe historic and ongoing steep population reductions due to overexploitation and habitat loss and degradation, with significant range contractions across their distribution. In the western Atlantic, the species is now extant in only four of its range states, with its 'presence uncertain' in 12 range states due to limited survey effort and few sightings, and it is 'possibly extinct' in three of its former range states. In the eastern Atlantic, of its former 18 range states, it is now extant in only five, has an uncertain presence in two, and is 'possibly extinct' in 11 states. Despite protection in some of its range states, threats are ongoing, and population decline is continuing. Due to limited abundance data, information on abundance trends was largely inferred from reports of capture records and local ecological knowledge, and this revealed populations have undergone high levels of decline over the past three generation lengths (59 years) in areas where it was historically extant, and is now either 'possibly extinct' or 'presence uncertain'. Only in the west Atlantic extant range states of the United States, some areas in Mexico, and the Bahamas are populations stable or increasing. Overall, it is inferred that the Smalltooth Sawfish has undergone a >80% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (59 years) due to overexploitation, habitat degradation, and reductions in extent of occurrence, and it is assessed as Critically Endangered (CR A2cd).
trade: Despite species-level protections in many countries across the range of the Smalltooth Sawfish, the species is still used for the fins, whole rostra, rostral teeth, meat, liver, and skin (McDavitt 2005). Sawfish fins are among the most valuable in the shark fin trade and although international trade of sawfishes and their products is prohibited since 2007 and 2013 when they were listed on the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) Appendix I, illegal international trade likely exists due to the high value of their products. Sawfish (Pristis spp.) fins have recently been reported from Hong Kong, albeit as a small proportion of fins sampled (CardeÃ±osa et al. 2020). In many parts of its range, the meat is generally consumed locally by coastal communities and does not usually enter the international trade, such as in the Bahamas (T. Guttridge pers. comm. 21 January 2022) and West Africa (R. Leeney unpubl. data 2022). In some West African countries, sawfish meat was the basis of a dish served as part of traditional ceremonies on the Bijago Archiplago, Guinea-Bissau (Leeney and Poncelet 2015). Sawfish rostra are used in traditional medicines, ceremonial weapons and as curios (McDavitt 2005). In West African countries, rostra were often kept by fishers and incorporated into local practices such as headdresses for ceremonial dances in Guinea-Bissau (Leeney and Poncelet 2015) or hung on the walls of a fisherâ€™s house as a decoration. The Smalltooth Sawfish is displayed in public aquaria.The use of sawfish rostral teeth for cockfighting spurs has been historically reported from PerÃº and other South American countries (Cogorno Ventura 2001), but recent reports highlight that this practice still occurs in Ecuador, PerÃº, Brazil, Bolivia, PanamÃ¡, and Costa Rica (Valerio-Vargas and Espinoza 2019, LÃ³pez-Angarita et al. 2021, P. Charvet unpubl data 2021, M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2022). The rostral teeth are mostly obtained from Brazil, Ecuador, PanamÃ¡, Costa Rica, and various Caribbean countries (CITES 2007, M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2022).

description: The Largetooth Sawfish (Pristis pristis) is a large (to 705 cm total length) euryhaline shark-like ray with a widespread circumtropical distribution comprising four subpopulations (Western Atlantic, Eastern Pacific, Eastern Atlantic, and Indo-West Pacific). The species occurs at depths of 0â€“60 m with juveniles occupying freshwater and estuarine habitats, and adults occurring in both estuarine and coastal waters. It is taken as bycatch (and was historically targeted) in commercial and small-scale fisheries and often retained for its meat and fins. Historically, its fins were considered among the most highly valued in the shark fin trade and this high value drove demand and increased exploitation of the species over the past decades throughout its range. Habitat loss and the morphology of the rostrum, which makes them susceptible to capture in fishing gear, have also driven declines independently of trade. International trade of all sawfish species was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 with their listing on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), however, illegal trade continues (especially for their rostra in Central and South America, but in some areas also for their meat and fins). All subpopulations have undergone severe historic and ongoing steep population reductions due to overexploitation and habitat loss and degradation with significant range contractions across their distribution. The species is now 'possibly extinct' in 19 of its 60 former range states, and in 14 range states its presence is currently uncertain due to limited survey effort or recent sightings. Despite protection in at least 17 of its range states, threats are ongoing and population decline is continuing. Based on limited catch data or information on abundance trends inferred from reports of capture records and local ecological knowledge, populations have undergone high levels of decline over the past three generation lengths (68 years). Overall, it is inferred that the Largetooth Sawfish has undergone a >80% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (68 years) due to overexploitation, habitat degradation, and reductions in extent of occurrence, and it is assessed as Critically Endangered A2cd.
trade: Despite species-level protections in many countries across the range of the Largetooth Sawfish, the species is still used for its fins, whole rostra, rostral teeth, meat, liver, and skin (McDavitt 2005). Sawfish fins are among the most valuable in the shark fin trade and although international trade of sawfishes and their products was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 when they were listed on CITES Appendix I, illegal international trade may still exist due to the high value of their products. Sawfish (Pristis spp.) fins have recently been reported from Hong Kong, albeit as a small proportion of fins sampled (CardeÃ±osa et al. 2020). The meat is generally consumed locally by coastal communities and does not usually enter the international trade. The species is displayed in public aquaria.The use of sawfish rostral teeth for cockfighting spurs has been historically reported from PerÃº and other South American countries (Cogorno Ventura 2001), but recent reports highlight that this practice still occurs in Ecuador, PanamÃ¡, and Costa Rica (Valerio-Vargas and Espinoza 2019, LÃ³pez-Angarita et al. 2021, M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2022). The rostral teeth are mostly obtained from Brazil, Ecuador, PanamÃ¡, Costa Rica, and various Caribbean countries (CITES 2007, M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2022). In the western Indian Ocean, rostra are used as fences and donated to churches and shrines (Tanna et al. 2021, M. Khan unpubl. data 2022). In Papua New Guinea, in addition to use of the fins and meat, the rostra are used for decorations, weapons, and rituals (Grant et al. 20121a, Grant et al. 2021b). In Australia, rostra were historically often retained, and it is likely that that this practice still occurs occasionally (Morgan et al. 2011).

description: The Green Sawfish (Pristis zijsron) is a large (up to 730 cm total length) shark-like ray with an Indo-Pacific distribution in tropical and subtropical waters. The species occurs at depths of 0â€“100 m with juveniles occupying nearshore and estuarine habitats and adults occurring in deeper continental shelf waters. Sawfish fins are among the most highly valued in the shark fin trade. This high value and international demand incentivized increased exploitation and retention of this species. International commercial trade of all five sawfish species was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 with their listing on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), however, illegal trade continues (especially for their fins and rostra). Habitat loss and the morphology of the rostrum, which makes them susceptible to capture in fishing gear, have also driven declines independently of trade. The Green Sawfish has undergone severe historic and ongoing population declines in most of its range due to overfishing and habitat loss and degradation, resulting in significant range contraction. The species is now â€˜possibly extinctâ€™ in 11 of its 36 range states, and its presence is uncertain in 11 range states. Based on limited catch data or information on abundance trends inferred from reports of capture records, and local ecological knowledge, populations have declined steeply over the past half century in most areas where it is still extant. Despite protection in at least five of its range states, threats are ongoing, and population decline is continuing. Overall, it is inferred that the Green Sawfish has undergone a >80% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (50 years) due to exploitation, habitat degradation, and reductions in extent of occurrence, and it is assessed as Critically Endangered (CR A2cd).
trade: Despite species-level protections in many countries, sawfishes are still used for their fins, whole rostra, rostral teeth, meat, organs, and skin (McDavitt 2005). Sawfish fins are among the most valuable in the shark fin trade and although international commercial trade of sawfishes and their products was prohibited in 2007 and 2013 when they were listed on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), illegal international trade may still exist due to the high value of their products. For example, Green Sawfish were calculated to have a mean retail price of USD$14,392, and a maximum value of potentially USD$27,940 (McClenachan et al. 2016). Sawfish (Pristis spp.) fins have recently been reported from Hong Kong, albeit as a small proportion of fins sampled (CardeÃ±osa et al. 2020). The meat is generally consumed locally by coastal communities and does not usually enter the international trade. Globally, there is a small trade in live sawfishes including Green Sawfish for display in public aquaria that has been strictly regulated since their CITES listing (White et al. 2017b, Buckley et al. 2018). In Pakistan, rostra have been used for religious purposes and were once sufficiently abundant that they were used as boundary fences in some coastal villages (Khan 2021). In Bangladesh, sawfishes are targeted for use in medicinal purposes and command a high market price (Hossain et al. 2015, Haque et al. 2020). In Papua New Guinea, sawfishes have a range of uses including consumption, sale of fins and meat, use of rostra for decorations or weapons, and some communities use sawfishes for ritualistic purposes (Leeney et al. 2018, Grant et al. 2021a, Grant et al. 2021b).Historical use and trade of Green Sawfish is similar to other sawfish species and occurred throughout its range, but is perhaps best documented from the Arabian Peninsula (Moore 2015). The impressive rostra of this species, which exceeds 1m in length in large individuals, makes them highly valued as a curio. In Australia, the Green Sawfish has been protected since 2009, prohibiting any use or trade. Although ongoing retention and trade of rostra still occurs, no data are available on the quantities. In 2020, a historic Green Sawfish rostrum sold in a New South Wales auction for over AUD$3,400 (B. Wueringer unpubl. data 2022).

description: The Spadenose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos buthi) is a small (to at least 69 cm total length) guitarfish endemic to the Gulf of California, Mexico in the Eastern Central Pacific. It is demersal on soft substrates in shallow coastal waters at depths of 0â€“10 m. The species was only recently described based on 80 specimens, and it is likely that the Spadenose Guitarfish is captured and misidentified as its regional congener, the Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus). Thus, based on the catches and trends of the Shovelnose Guitarfish, the Spadenose Guitarfish is targeted by artisanal elasmobranch fisheries and taken as bycatch by commercial demersal trawls and gillnets, and retained for its meat and fins. There are no population trend data, however Mexican fisheries logbook data suggest fluctuating catches of all guitarfishes combined from 2007 to 2014 despite suspected stable effort. Declines have been noted in other species of sharks and rays in the Gulf of California artisanal fisheries and declines in guitarfishes are also likely. The actual levels of exploitation are high across the known spatial and depth range of the Spadenose Guitarfish, and it has no refuge from unmanaged fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Spadenose Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
trade: There is no use or trade information for this species but its close relative and regional congener, the Shovelnose Guitarfish, is used for its meat and fins (Farrugia et al. 2016), and it is likely this species is also used for the meat and fins.
country: Mexico

description: The Brazilian Guitarfish (Pseudobatos horkelii) is a small (to 138 cm total length) shark-like ray that occurs in the Southwest Atlantic from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to northernÂ Argentina. It is demersal on soft substrates of the continental shelf inshore toÂ 150 m depth. It is captured in intense and largely unmanaged commercial and artisanal demersal trawl, gillnet, longline, and beach seine fisheries throughout its geographic range. There are three estimates of population reduction. First, in Rio Grande do Sul, total landings increased from 842 t in 1975 to 1,804 t in 1984 and then declined continuously to 157 t in 2001, the equivalent of a >99% reduction over three generations (55.5 years). Second, the average research trawl catch-per-unit-effort of Brazilian Guitarfish in southern Brazil over the years 1993 to 1999 was 17% of that observed during 1975 to 1986, also the equivalent of a >99% reduction over three generations.Â Fisheries remain intense and unmanaged there. Third, in Uruguay, this guitarfish is captured frequently in gillnets and longlines, is landed, and is sometimes targeted, and it is also captured in artisanal trawl fisheries. Catches from research trawls there in the 1980s and early 1990s were on average around 1,400 kg/hr, and between 2013 and 2017 were only 480 kg/hr, the equivalent of a >92% reduction over three generations. In Argentina, it is suspected that intense and inadequately managed gillnet fishing pressure has led to declines in abundance there as well. Overall, due to intense and inadequately managed fishing pressure throughout its range, and steep population declines, it is inferred that the Brazilian Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of >80% over the past three generations (55.5 years), and it is assessed as Critically Endangered A2bd.
trade: This guitarfish is utilized bycatch across its range, and in some areas is targeted (e.g. Silveira et al. 2018). The meat is consumed or sold locally, and can fetch a high price (P. Charvet unpubl. data 2018).
country: Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay

description: The Freckled Guitarfish (Pseudobatos lentiginosus) is a small (to 78 cm total length) benthic shark-like ray that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean from North Carolina, United States of America (USA) to Nicaragua including the Gulf of Mexico and in the Southwest Atlantic off Brazil to a depth of 30 m. Its sandy habitat is largely untrawled in the USA providing some refuge for this species. Elsewhere, it is targeted and taken as bycatch in coastal artisanal and commercial trawl, handline, and gillnet fisheries that are intense and unmanaged in parts of its range. For example, it is prevalent in Mexican shrimp trawl fisheries and is the third-most caught species in bycatch In the Mexican Caribbean. Although data are sparse in Central America and northern South America, fisheries there are intense in some areas and are largely unmanaged. In northern Brazil, unmanaged trawling and gillnetting has led to steep declines and local extinctions of several sharks and rays. Habitat loss and degradation due to coastal development and oil exploration are also threats to this species in many parts of its range. Overall, due to the level of intense and unmanaged fishing pressure across its range, outside of USA waters, it is suspected that the Freckled Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the past three generation lengths (18 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cd.
trade: Guitarfishes are typically utilised for their meat. Fins are too small to be of value in the fin trade (Last et al. 2016).
country: Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, United States of America

description: The Whitesnout Guitarfish (Pseudobatos leucorhynchus) is a small (to 106 cm total length) shark-like ray that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from central Baja California, Mexico to northern Peru, including the southern Gulf of California and the GalÃ¡pagos Islands. It inhabits inshore areas with sandy substrates to a depth of 50 m. This guitarfish is captured in industrial demersal shrimp trawl fisheries and in artisanal gillnets and longlines. These fisheries are intense throughout most of its range. It is caught in low but increasing numbers in the southern Gulf of California multi-species artisanal gillnet fishery, which has been responsible for the depletion of various marine species. In San Felipe, Mexico, guitarfishes in general made up over 22% of elasmobranch bycatch in the industrial teleost trawl fishery. In Costa Rica, this guitarfish is considered to be moderately to highly susceptible to declines from industrial shrimp trawl fishing. There may be some refuge from industrial fishing in the GalÃ¡pagos Islands, but illegal fishing is an ongoing issue there. Overall, due to intense unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its rangeÂ and its occurrence in shallow coastal waters (without any refuge from fishing in deeper waters), it is suspected that the Whitesnout Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the past three generation lengths (18 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
trade: This guitarfish is retained in multi-species fisheries and the meat is dried and sold locally.
country: Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama

description: The Chola Guitarfish (Pseudobatos percellens) is a small (to 100 cm total length) shark-like ray that occurs patchily in the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic Oceans from Quintana Roo, Mexico to ParanÃ¡, Brazil from nearshore to 110 m depth. It is targeted and taken as bycatch in coastal artisanal and commercial trawl, handline, and gillnet fisheries that are intense and unmanaged in parts of its range. For example, it is prevalent in Mexican shrimp trawl fisheries and is the second-most caught species in bycatch. Although data are sparse in Central America and northern South America, fisheries there are intense in some areas and are largely unmanaged. In northern Brazil, unmanaged trawling and gillnetting has led to steep declines and local extinctions of several sharks and rays. Habitat loss and degradation due to coastal development, oil exploration, and pollution are also threats to this species in many parts of its range. There are no population size estimates, however, due to the level of unmanaged and intensifying fishing pressure across its range, the near-disappearance of other elasmobranchs including similar species, and coastal habitat degradation, it is suspected that the Chola Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 50â€“79% over the past three generation lengths (30 years), and it is assessed as Endangered A2cd.
trade: Meat is sold for use as human food. Young small specimens are taken for the aquarium trade in northeastern South America (P. Charvet unpubl. data 2019).
country: Brazil, Colombia, French Guiana [FR], Guyana, Jamaica, Panama, Suriname, Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic of)

description: The Pacific Guitarfish (Pseudobatos planiceps) is a small (to at least 125 cm total length) shark-like ray which occurs from southern Mexico to northern Chile and the GalÃ¡pagosÂ Islands (Ecuador) in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters to a depth of 50 m. This species is targeted either directly (e.g., in Peru) or as part of multi-species fisheries using gillnet, longline, and beach-seine. It is also a bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and small-scale gillnet fisheries and is usually retained for its meat. Fisheries operate throughout most of the range of the species with inadequate management or enforcement and the species has little refuge from fishing activities. It is under particularly heavy fishing pressure in Peru where it is the third most landed ray species. Overall, given the intensity of fishing pressure throughout its range and its susceptibility to capture, it is suspected that the Pacific GuitarfishÂ has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the last three generation lengths (15 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
trade: This guitarfish is retained and the meat is consumed or sold locally.
country: Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru

description: The Gorgona Guitarfish (Pseudobatos prahli) is a small (to at least 90 cm total length) shark-like ray that occurs from southern Mexico to northern Peru in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. It inhabits shallow inshore and continental shelf waters to a depth of 70 m. This species is a bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries and small-scale gillnet and longline fisheries. It is rarely encountered in Mexico and is not common in fisheries in Costa Rica, Colombia, and Peru but is abundant in Ecuador where it may be targeted or is taken as bycatch in small-scale fisheries. Fisheries operate throughout most of the range of the species with inadequate management or enforcement, but the species is associated with rocky habitat which would give it some refuge from trawling. Overall, given the intensity of fishing pressure throughout its range (particularly in Ecuador which appears to be its core range) and itsÂ susceptibilityÂ to capture, it is suspected that the Gorgona GuitarfishÂ has undergone a population reduction of 30â€“49% over the last three generation lengths (15 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
trade: This guitarfish is retained and the meat is consumed or sold locally.
country: Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru

description: This is an amended version of the 2014 assessment to accommodate recent taxonomic revision of the genus Rhinobatus.The Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus) is a medium-sized guitarfish that inhabits shallow coastal waters in the Eastern Central Pacific from central California (USA) to the southern Gulf of California (Mexico). This species is typically found at depths <12 m, but has been recorded to 91.5 m. This guitarfish has a generation length of 9 years and exhibits an annual reproductive cycle with litters of 1-16 pups.In Mexican waters, this species is taken in directed artisanal elasmobranch fisheries in both the Gulf of California and on the Pacific coast of Baja California, and is also retained as bycatch by demersal trawls and gillnets. This guitarfish is the most heavily targeted batoid in north Pacific Mexico. Catches of the BahÃ­a Almejas fishery in Baja California Sur declined severely following a large increase in effort during the mid- to late 1990s.Â In Californian waters, recreational fishing derby data from Elkhorn Slough, central CaliforniaÂ suggest that this species has declined by 74% over three generations.Â Landings in California have also declined, although these declines do not necessarily correspond to population declines.Â In 2012, an annual seasonal closure on elasmobranchÂ fishing was implemented from May 1 to July 31 along the Mexican Pacific coast, and other recent monitoring and management changes have been made in Mexico.Â Nonetheless, given ongoing target and bycatch fisheries for this species in Mexico, an absence of species-specific data in Mexican logbooks, and recreational fishing derbies in the United States, the Shovelnose Guitarfish is is assessed as Near Threatened, as we suspect that this species has declined by nearly 30% over the past three generations.
trade: This species is utilized for its meat and fins.
country: Mexico, United States of America

description: The Bowmouth Guitarfish (Rhina ancylostoma) is a medium-sized (to 270 cm total length) shark-like ray with a wide distribution in the Indo-West Pacific from South Africa to New Caledonia and north to Japan. It occurs in coastal and continental shelf waters from close inshore to depths of at least 70 m. Wedgefishes have limited biological productivity; the Bowmouth Guitarfish has litter sizes of 2-11 pups and an estimated generation length of 15 years.Â The â€˜whiteâ€™ fins of shark-like rays (including sawfishes, wedgefishes, and giant guitarfishes)Â are considered the best quality fins for human consumption and are among the highest valued in the international shark fin trade. The meat is of high quality and generally consumed locally. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across the range of the Bowmouth Guitarfish, and as a result, targeted and incidental fishing effort is placing significant pressure on all wedgefish species in the Indo-West Pacific. Where wedgefishes and giant guitarfishes have been targeted or exploited as incidental catch, severe declines, population depletions, and localized disappearances have occurred. Severe population reduction in the Bowmouth Guitarfish is inferredÂ from actual levels of exploitation, as well as several historical accounts and contemporary datasets from Iran, Pakistan, India, Thailand, and Indonesia. While some parts of Australasia provide refuge from intense fishing effort, this proportion of the speciesâ€™ range is not considered to be large enough relative to the global range to lower the assessment. It is inferred that the Bowmouth GuitarfishÂ has undergone a >80% population reduction over the last three generations (45 years) and it is assessed as Critically Endangered A2bd.
trade: Wedgefishes are heavily utilized across their range for the meat and fins.Â The exception for this species is Australia where wedgefishes are generally not utilized or traded.Â While little species-specific information is available, the following provides a generalized account of use and trade globally.Â The meat is of good quality and a food source for many coastal communities in tropical countries where it is generally consumed locally, although it also enters the international trade in dried and salted form (e.g., Moore 2017, Jabado 2018). Large whole wedgefishes (>200 cm total length; TL) have been traded for a high value of up to US$680 each, however, smaller specimens, and even large Bowmouth Guitarfish (>150 cm TL) can sell for low valueÂ (e.g. Jabado 2018). The â€˜whiteâ€™ fins of shark-like rays (including wedgefishes and giant guitarfishes)Â are considered the best quality fins for human consumption and are among the highest valued in the international shark fin trade (Suzuki 2002, Dent and Clarke 2015, Moore 2017). Fin prices in the literature include US$396/kg for wedgefish fins (Chen 1996) and an average price of US$276/kg and US$185/kg for Qun chi (fins from shark-like rays) in Guangzhou (mainland China) and Hong Kong, respectively (HauÂ et al. 2018). The skin may be dried and traded internationally as a luxury leather product (Haque et al. 2018). The eggs of shark-like raysÂ are sometimes dried and consumed locally while the heads may also be dried and used as either fish meal or fertilizer (Haque et al. 2018, R.W. Jabado unpubl. data).
country: Australia, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, China, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Djibouti, Egypt, Eritrea, Hong Kong, SAR, India, Indonesia, Iran (Islamic Republic of), Iraq, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Kenya, Kuwait, Macao, SAR, Malaysia, Mauritius, Mozambique, Myanmar, New Caledonia, Oman, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Qatar, Republic of Korea, Saudi Arabia, Seychelles, Singapore, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Taiwan, Province of China, Thailand, Timor-Leste, United Arab Emirates, United Republic of Tanzania, Viet Nam, Yemen

description: The Whale Shark (Rhincodon typus) is a large (to 18â€“20 m total length) shark that occurs across tropical and warm temperate oceans. This highly mobile species is found in coastal and oceanic habitats to a depth of at least 1,928 m. Genetic results indicate that two major subpopulations exist, in the Atlantic Ocean and Indo-Pacific, respectively. Pronounced size- and sex-based segregation is present in most of the speciesâ€™ known feeding and transit areas, with coastal sites typically dominated by juvenile male sharks. The largest known aggregation sites for Whale Sharks host hundreds or low thousands of individuals, based on identified individual sharks and model estimates. Although individual sharks are highly mobile, many show a degree of site fidelity, and limited direct connectivity has been observed across large geographical scales.Â Major contemporary threats at the global level include incidental catch in a wide range of net fisheries and serious injury and inferred mortality through vessel strikes. If landed, the meat is consumed locally and the fins are likely to enter international trade. Target and incidental catch fisheries have impacted Whale Sharks in the Indo-Pacific, and there is substantial evidence for a reduction of large adult sharks, decreases in catch-per-unit-effort from fisheries, and declining sightings-per-unit-effort from fisheries and sight-resight studies. While a number of commercial fisheries for the species closed during the 1990â€“2000s, the species still faces a significant level of threat. Based on count data, modelled population estimates and habitat availability, 75% of the global Whale Shark population is inferred to occur in the Indo-Pacific, and 25% in the Atlantic. An overall decline of >65% is inferred in the Indo-Pacific over the last 120 years (three generations), resulting in a subpopulation assessment of Endangered. In the Atlantic Ocean, the overall population decline is considered to be lower at â‰¥30%, resulting in a subpopulation assessment of Vulnerable. Given the bulk of the global population occurs in the Indo-Pacific, based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation,Â a population reduction of 50â€“79% was inferred over the last three generations (120 years).Â Therefore, the species is assessed as Endangered A2bd.
trade: Historically, Whale Sharks have been subject to target fisheries driven by, in some areas, local consumption and use, and the international trade of derivative products. Animals incidentally caught are often utilized, and some national and international trade occurs. Whale Sharks are also a focal species for wildlife tourism industries in many countries.Atlantic OceanOccasional Whale Shark catches have occurred in the Atlantic Ocean since at least 1912 (Gudger 1941). A targeted fishery was present in Santa Cruz, Cuba, where 8â€“9 sharks were caught each year until the fishery was banned in 1991 (Graham 2007). In Venezuela, two Whale Sharks were reportedly harpooned by fishers prior to 1976 (Romero et al. 2000), and up to 21 sharks were opportunistically caught between 2014â€“2017 and their fins sold (SÃ¡nchez et al. 2020). Following targeted conservation efforts between 2018â€“2020, no further retention was reported from this fishery (SÃ¡nchez et al. 2020). There are no other records of targeted catches of Whale Sharks or trade from this subpopulation.Indo-PacificExtensive use and trade have occurred in the Indo-Pacific region. Here, Whale Sharks have been caught commercially in fisheries since at least the 1850s (Gudger 1941), including for the international export of their fins (e.g., from India to China; Bean 1907). However, before the 1980s, they were rarely targeted (Silas 1986, Hsu et al. 2012, Acebes 2013), but rather harpooned opportunistically or landed as incidental catch. Whale Shark muscle tissue has a high water content and has generally been considered unpalatable, or at least of low value, across much of their distribution (Silas 1986, Colman 1997, Acebes 2013). The liver was the primary reason for catches being landed in many areas, as the liver oil could be used as a preservative for the timber used in boat hulls (Silas 1986, Anderson and Ahmed 1993, Hanfee 2001, Akhilesh et al. 2013). Some Whale Sharks were taken specifically for their liver in India as early as 1955â€“1960 (Hanfee 2001). Fishers in the Maldives used to take 20â€“30 individuals per year for their oil, but reported declining catches during the 1980s to early 1990s (Anderson and Ahmed 1993), and the fishery was banned in 1995. Occasional hunting may have continued following protection (Riley et al. 2009).Â Prior to 1985, there was little demand for Whale Shark meat in Taiwan, although the species was caught regularly as incidental catch in set-net fisheries (Chen et al. 1997). Specimens of several tons in weight sold at US$200â€“300 (Chen and Phipps 2002). A meat fishery developed during the 1990s, with annual catches accelerating to 272 individuals in 1996, derived from both set-net and harpoon fisheries. Whale Shark became the most expensive shark meat available in Taiwan by 1997, reaching prices of US$13.93/kg. A small 2 tonne (t) Whale Shark could by then fetch US$14,000, with a larger 10 t shark selling for around US$70,000 in 1997 (Chen et al. 1997). Catches declined from this peak to 80â€“100 sharks throughout the country each year after 1997 (Hsu et al. 2012). The annual volume of Whale Shark meat traded more than doubled between 1998 and 2000, however, to 60 t in 2000 (Chen and Phipps 2002). Market surveys in 2001 indicated that catches were being under-reported in official statistics and that significant quantities of Whale Shark meat were also being imported through unofficial channels (Chen and Phipps 2002). Following the introduction of specific export codes for Whale Shark meat in 2001, no imports and 2 t of exports were recorded over the following yearâ€”mostly to Spain, and valued at US$1.15/kg (Chen and Phipps 2002). Concern for the status of the species led to total allowable catch quotas being steadily reduced down to zero sharks over the 2001â€“2007 period (Hsu et al. 2012). A total of 693 sharks were caught in Taiwan between 2001 and 2008 (Hsu et al. 2012). Whale Sharks are still regularly encountered in Taiwanâ€™s set net fisheries but, since 2007, they have been released by fishers once caught due to comprehensive fishing bans (Hsu et al. 2012).Â The increase in value and demand for Whale Shark meat in Taiwan led to buyers seeking international suppliers (Hanfee 2001, Chen and Phipps 2002, Acebes 2013). In the Bohol Sea of the Philippines, this led to former marine mammal hunters switching to Whale Sharks, and the improved profit enabled boat owners to invest in larger, faster vessels (Acebes 2013). From 1990 to 1997, 624â€“627 Whale Sharks were caught from four of the primary fishing sites in the Philippines (Alava and DolumbalÃ³ 2002). When Whale Sharks were protected in the Maldives and the Philippines in 1998, Indian exporters realised that Whale Shark exports could prove lucrative and encouraged more fishers there to start targeting the species (Hanfee 2001). Between 1889 and 1998, 1,974 Whale Sharks were recorded as landed in India (Pravin 2000). Surveys in Gujarat from 1999 to 2000 recorded about 600 Whale Sharks landed, with some additional reports received following the cessation of on-site catch monitoring (Hanfee 2001). Following a conservation campaign, Whale Sharks were legally protected in Indian territorial waters in 2001 (Akhilesh et al. 2013). However, landings of Whale Sharks are still documented across India, especially on the coast Andhra Pradesh (e.g., Sathiyaselvam et al. 2016), and in many cases derivative products such as meat are utilised by coastal communities. Similarly, in Pakistan, commercial fisheries for Whale Shark were closed in the 1970s. However, if landed, animals are consumed locally or used as raw material for fishmeal, while fins enter the international trade (Moazzam Khan pers. comm. 03/06/2025).Whale Shark meat from mainland China was historically likely also exported to the Taiwanese market (Chen and Phipps 2002). Though Whale Sharks were not necessarily targeted off mainland China, there was a large incidental catch, estimated at more than 1,000 individuals per annum, due to the intense fishing pressure of the Chinese fleet (Li et al. 2012). Whale Sharks were considered to be a high-value catch in the fishery (Li et al. 2012). An NGO exposÃ© on the "planet's biggest slaughter of Whale Sharks" at Puqi markets in Zhejiang province, reported that at least 600 Whale Sharks were processed per year based on investigations from 2010 to 2013 (WildLifeRisk 2014). After the meat, the most profitable product was liver oil, which was extracted for use in cosmetics and health supplements (WildLifeRisk 2014). Whale Shark filter pads also have commercial value in Chinese trade, likely as a substitution for mobulid ray gill plates (O'Malley et al. 2017, Steinke et al. 2017). Reports from Puqi, which remains the most important processing hub for sharks in China, suggest that the scale of the shark fishing industry overall has substantially contracted in recent years (Wu 2016). This may indicate a decline in the number of Whale Sharks being caught, although small quantities of Whale Shark products have been reported from Chinese trade surveys (O'Malley et al. 2017, Steinke et al. 2017). The current status of the Chinese Whale Shark fishery is unclear.Whale Shark fins can also have high trade value (McClenachan et al. 2016). While international trade in Whale Shark fins has taken place for well over a century (Bean 1907), they were regarded as low value in Taiwan in the 1990s due to poor quality and the difficulty of their preparation (Chen and Phipps 2002). Demand for Whale Shark fins within the broader shark fin trade was minimal, despite sometimes being sold as display fins for shark fin soup restaurants (Chen and Phipps 2002). A survey of the Indian fishery, however, found that the fins were a high-value export product to Hong Kong SAR, Singapore, Taiwan, and the USA; fishers were paid up to US$1,100 per set of fins in 1999 (Hanfee 2001). Chinese surveys found that Whale Shark fins obtained high prices (Li et al. 2012, WildLifeRisk 2014). Occasional reports of Whale Shark fins and meat being taken in various countries, including Bangladesh (Haque et al. 2019), off Ecuador (Bonaccorso et al. 2021), the Maldives (Riley et al. 2009), Indonesia (White and Cavanagh 2007), and Venezuela (SÃ¡nchez et al. 2020), and their occasional presence in trade surveys (O'Malley et al. 2017, Steinke et al. 2017), indicate that some international trade may persist, though domestic use for catches cannot be ruled out in some of these cases.After starting at Ningaloo Reef in Western Australia in the 1980s, tourism industries based on swimming with or viewing Whale Sharks have now developed at 27 wild sites in 19 countries or territories, as well as eight sites where Whale Sharks are provisioned, and multiple aquarium exhibits (Ziegler and Dearden 2021). For example, in the Philippines, there are at least three provisioning sites in southern Bohol developed in 2019â€“2024, hosting 1â€“15 individuals daily, and in northern Mindanao Whale Sharks are seasonally encountered (Novemberâ€“May) in Macajalar, Gingoog and Butuan bays (Alava and DolumbalÃ³ 2002, Eckert et al. 2002, Araujo et al. 2018). Excluding aquaria, sites around the world attract around 980,000 people, with an economic value of more than US$139 million in 2019 (Ziegler and Dearden 2021).
